I note with some concern that recently we have seen the emergence of supposed pro-integration, pro-Indonesian forces on the streets in Dili engaged in potential conflict with pro-independence forces. It is interesting to see that development. It is disturbing and I would ask questions about the precise origins of these forces and what their agenda actually is.

Australia should be involved in putting substantial pressure on Indonesia now that the opportunity has arisen to release Xanana Gusmao and engage in serious dialogue and negotiations about a final conclusion to this very sad and sorry affair in our region. Australia should be putting pressure on Indonesia to withdraw its troops to allow the East Timorese people to take a much more substantial interim role in their own governance, their own activities and their own economic development. Australia should ensure that some strategy for reconciliation be pursued which does at least create the possibility that alternatives of association and some degree of friendship can be there for the future, rather than prolonged enmity, hatred and bitterness, which clearly have very substantial reasons for existing. Australia is very well positioned to correct its previous mistakes and to put pressure on Indonesia to finally give justice to the people of East Timor. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âFirst of all, let me commend the honourable member for Calare (Mr Andren) for his motion before the House today. It is a commendable motion. Like everybody else in this place, I welcome the strong bipartisan nature of this debate on the points that he has made in that motion.

speech.para: I do not think anybody either in this place or the other place or anybody involved in the political spectrum in Australia welcomes what happened two decades ago in East Timor. Nevertheless, it is now part of sovereign Indonesia and it is for the Indonesians and the East Timorese to solve the problem. Australia can apply pressures, and there is no doubt that East Timor is a deeply divided and troubled place.

The bipartisan nature of this debate, of course, strengthens Australia's approach to the bilateral relationship with Indonesia. Here is an opportunityâas indeed has happened from the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Downer) downâto make sure that the East Timorese have the ability and the wherewithal to make their case. It is very pleasing to considerâas indicated in this motionâwhat, in fact, is possible in the coming months as a result of a change of administration in Jakarta.

A satisfactory resolution of the problems will require dialogue not only with the government in Jakarta but also amongst the East Timorese themselves. The Australian government does not think that there are simplistic solutions to this problem; it is a delicate, very complex situation. Nevertheless, it is something that we should not shy away from and we should provide the appropriate support we can as a nation in our bilateral relationship with Indonesia.

We have made it very clear that the strength of that bilateral relationship includes the ability of Australia from time to time to be critical of the Republic of Indonesia on some of these issues. There is no doubt that is what this governmentâfrom the foreign minister downâhas done, and I have to say that in the previous administration there were criticisms made as well. The strength of our bilateral relationship is the degree to which we have the ability to objectively criticise things that are abhorrent to everybody, irrespective of the sovereign country to which one belongs.

The Australian government particularly welcomes the discussions between President Habibie and Bishop Belo and agrees that these talks hopefully will lead to resolution of the issues in East Timor. I have to agree with the honourable member for Aston (Mr Nugent) who drew attention to Minister Muladi's comments and put a caveat on what he had to say about strong legal evidence. I do not want to start the hares running and to put a stopper on anything that might happen, but I think we have to be realistic about this and understand that there is a lot of groundwork to be done before substantive progress can be made.

The Australian government has continuously argued for a reduction in the military presence in East Timor. It is pleasing, of course, that the President has indicated that he is prepared to reduce the number of troops in East Timor and indeed to explore avenues of greater autonomy in that particular region. I am very pleased to provide support to the commendable motion of the honourable member for Calare. Let us hope that in the interests of stability in this region, particularly for the East Timorese people, this situation can be resolved peacefully and quickly.

talk.start.para: âOrder! The time allotted for this debate has expired. The debate is therefore adjourned and the resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day for the next sitting.

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 23 March, on motion by Mr Eoin Cameron:
That the House:
(1) acknowledges the contribution of palliative care to the proper treatment of patients with a terminal illness;

(2) recognises the work of health professionals and volunteers in the field of palliative care and commends those workers for their commitment to patients, the compassion with which they undertake their work and the commitment they have to palliative care as a proper treatment of patients with a terminal illness;
(3) acknowledges the benefits to patients, families and health care providers of palliative care;
(4) further recognises the benefits to both patients and families of palliative care provided to patients in their home rather than at medical institutions;
(5) urges the Government to continue the provision of funds to palliative care with a view to increasing funding to palliative care provided at home in particular; and

(6) implores the Government to investigate the merit of encouraging the provision of palliative care at the patient's home, and the funding for this, in view of the benefits for both the patient and their family as well as the Government.

talk.start.para: âI am pleased to speak on the motion submitted by the member for Stirling, Mr Eoin Cameron, on palliative care. I notice in his contribution he suggested that perhaps he did not have a conflict of interest, notwithstanding the fact that his daughter was a palliative care nurse. I concur with that view. In the same spirit, I want to say that my wife is involved in the Governor Phillip Day Hospital, and one of the most frustrating things I find is respecting the confidences entrusted to me as a husband, rather than as a member, about the frustra tions of wanting to provide a first-class service to the elderly.

speech.para: I think all those involved in the delivery of services to the elderlyâand this is no less and probably more so in palliative careâreally do have a special gift. I examine my soul from time to time and reluctantly find that it is not one of the gifts that were handed out to me. Some argue that very few were, and who am I to disagree with that?

The other area of conflict, of course, is that I was chairman of the local committee agitating for the Mount Druitt Hospital and was pleased, once it was open, to serve as deputy chairman to both Bishop Murphy and Bishop Heather. There was no more pleasing thing for me to see, just before this two-week session of parliament started, than the opening of the Reverend Sister Christina Harcombe Palliative Care Unit.

The focus of palliative care is neither to hasten nor postpone death. It provides relief from pain and other distressing symptoms and integrates the psychological and spiritual aspects of care. Furthermore, it offers a support system to help relatives and friends cope during the patient's illness, and bereavement.

One of the many good things the Labor government did was to announce in 1993-94 a four-year program to provide palliative care costing some $55 million. Of course, in 1998 that agreement has run out, and it is disturbing to hear the government claim that it is providing new palliative care money whereas in reality it is part of that ongoing program. The unit that has been opened provides 16 palliative care beds. The idea is to provide choice for families and choice for the patient. It will be not only the centre, if you like, of the acute delivery of care but also a 24-hour support system, including community nursing care, with access to allied health professionals so that the patients can be supported not only in the unit but more particularly at home. That was a particular thrust of the member for Stirling, and I am very pleased to see in the opening of this palliative care unit under the Carr Labor government that the thrust of the member's motion has indeed been picked up. It is a matter of regret to me that in the western suburbs of Sydney we have so few palliative care units.

Like the member for Stirling, I think one of the most difficult debates that members participated in was on the Kevin Andrews bill on euthanasia. Much was made of those who, like me, voted against the euthanasia bill but focused on the need to improve palliative care services. It is really incumbent on both sides, as this motion tends to indicate, that we do not accept the status quo but rather increase the funding. Reverend Christina Harcombe was someone known to me. She was the religious coordinator at the hospital for many years. I am very pleased that her particular contribution to Mount Druitt Hospital has been recognised in this way. Unfortunately, she is not in a position to understand the honour her service has attracted. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âIn the past decade, the words `palliative care' and `hospice' have found a new place in the lexicon of health care in Australia. To palliate is to relieve; hence the use of the term `palliative care' to describe the provision of pain relieving care for people with terminal illnesses such as cancer, debilitating conditions like motor neurone disease and some respiratory and circulatory illnesses.

speech.para: Palliative care is delivered by a health care team. It concentrates on the quality of life and alleviating pain and other distressing symptoms. It aims neither to hasten nor postpone death, but to ensure that the person is cared for in a holistic manner, with dignity and without pain. It addresses the psychological and pastoral needs of patients, their families and carers, and supports these people in their bereavement.

Palliative care is delivered in both hospices, that is, special hospitals for the dying, and at home. The development of palliative care is one of the most unremarked aspects of health care in Australia, but I believe it is one of the most important. In a sense, the modern development of palliative care is a return to one of the traditional roles of health care. The Order of Malta, which supports hospices at Caritas Christi in Melbourne and Mount Olivet in Brisbane, was established as a hospice- infirmary for pilgrims to Palestine by the armies of the First Crusade before the taking of Jerusalem in 1099. Indeed, next year marks the 900th anniversary of the provision of hospice services throughout the world by this organisation.

The renewed interest in palliative care reflects the work of two significant women. One, Dr Elisabeth Kubler-Ross, began to break down the taboos about death and dying with a series of books, beginning in the 1970s, the most notable of which is entitled On Death and Dying. The other, Dame Cicely Saunders, provided a model for modern palliative care with her remarkable work at St Christopher's Hospice in London.

Regrettably, as other members have indicated, palliative care has trailed the more glamorous fields of modern scientific medicine for some time. But this is changing, both in the training of doctors and nurses and in the provision of services. The Commonwealth government has provided more than $25 million a year in funding of palliative care through Medicare schedule G and the palliative care program. The palliative care program was designed to maximise the quality of life of people suffering a terminal illness, to avoid inappropriate hospital admissions and to provide support for families and carers. The funding has also allowed some states to review and improve the delivery of their palliative care services. I note that the principles for the new Australian health care agreements between the Commonwealth and the states provide for the continuation of this funding under one stream.

Having served on the board of a hospice for some years, and having witnessed the remarkable work of the medical and nursing staff, and the many volunteers who contribute their time, their energy and their caring to outreach home hospice services, I can attest to the remarkable work undertaken by these people for the community. I am honoured to support the motion of the honourable member for Stirling (Mr Eoin Cameron). In doing so, I note that 12-18 July is National Palliative Care Week in Australia. I hope that more Australians learn of these valuable health services, and I urge both the Commonwealth and state governments to continue to support palliative care services through the provision of adequate funding.

Palliation is not just about people with cancer, and not just for people with terminal illnesses such as AIDS. Palliation is about helping people end their days with comfort and dignity, providing support and compassion to the dying as well as strength and solace to grieving family and friends. Few activities could be more valuable. I too commend the motion to the House.

talk.start.para: âI am sure that when members speak on this private member's motion relating to palliative care their thoughts go to their own friends and relatives who have found it necessary to receive this form of care in their final years. I would hope that the six points contained in this private member's motion will encourage this government and future governments to ensure that adequate funds are available for this type of care. I refer to the definition of palliative care as defined by the Australian Community Health Association:

speech.para: Palliative care refers to the physical, emotional, spiritual and social care of individuals with a progressive incurable illness and their families and carers.

This type of care was provided originally for people with cancer where death was imminent. However, more recently palliative care is being offered to people who have a variety of incurable diseases and who may be early on in the course of their illness; for example, people who are living with HIV/AIDS and those with end-stage organ failure.

In the same document, Health outcomes: the case of palliative care, we are advised that palliative care incorporates a blend of skills from several health care disciplines. It also recognises that dying is more than a collection of symptoms of disease; it is a complex physical and spiritual process. It is acknowledged that families, carers and patients are all involved in the process and should be incorporated in the plan of care. Palliative care is an acknowledgment that death is not a medical failure but a part of life. Through adequate support of palliative care services, the crisis of death can be lessened for the patient, family and friends.

I am further indebted to information contained in a book entitled Euthanasia: should we kill the dying?, by Dr Brian Pollard, for the following insight into the appropriate care for people who are seriously ill. It made the point that, at a certain advanced stage of serious illness, the type of medical treatment changes from the hope of curing the patient to treatment that relieves their physical and emotional distress and the imparting of detailed information to the patient. Dr Pollard's list of components of palliative care are: control of physical symptoms, emotional support and communication, respecting the patient's wishes, teamwork and the family.

I would like to make a brief comment on the control of physical symptoms. Dr Pollard makes some interesting points relating to providing palliative care for cancer patients. While cancer is not the most common cause of death, it is a disease that may eventually lead to death and is therefore associated in the public mind with fear about its future course. He suggests that most of medicine's most powerful weapons against cancer are themselves capable of producing disability and distress, and their usefulness is generally limited to prolonging life rather than curing the disease. He says that a significant part of cancer pain is due to the treatment of the disease.
Of all the distresses of dying, pain is the most prominent and the most feared. According to Dr Pollard:

There are very few pains of cancer which today cannot be either totally eliminated or brought to the point where the patient can bear the small amount of residual pain. While the relief of this residual pain may require the help of an expert, most cancer pain is well within the competence of any doctor to treat it effectively.

I am pleased to advise that a new $1.8 million palliative care unit has recently been opened in the grounds of Mount Druitt Hospital. This unit will significantly enhance the quality of care for terminally ill patients in western Sydney. The unit will cater for patients who want to be cared for in their homes or in one of the unit's 16 in-patient beds. It is important that terminally ill patients have a choice of remaining in their own homes, surrounded by their families, with the knowledge that they have the support of experienced health professionals.

I congratulate the New South Wales state government for its contribution to palliative care in western Sydney. The community and staff of Mount Druitt Hospital have raised $40,000 for special items of equipment, and the palliative care unit is one component of a $96 million redevelopment of health services in Mount Druitt and Blacktown.

I am also pleased to refer to improvements in palliative care for our culturally diverse society. I refer to a special report in the autumn edition of Palliative Care News entitled `Improving palliative care in a multicultural environment.' This project sought to identify through consultation the needs and issues which impact on the care of patients and on their carers, service providers and ethnic community groups, and to identify models of palliative care services which are sensitive to cultural diversity. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âI am pleased to support this motion by the member for Stirling (Mr Eoin Cameron). I know that many members on both sides of the House agree that palliative care is a very important health issue but, of course, it is much more than just a health issue. The care of patients with terminal illnesses is a unique and special task. We pay tribute in this motion to special people, both health professionals and volunteers, who perform this task with great dedication and commitment. I can only imagine how tough it is for themânot just the professional judgment required in making decisions on how best to care for their patient but also in being there to help their loved ones through a very emotional and difficult time.

speech.para: Much as we have become more open as a society in the 1990s and we discuss our feelings freely on a range of issues, death and dying is still a taboo subject in many respects. It is one of those things that we tend to gloss over and, inevitable as it is for each of us, I think we live our lives with an `it won't happen to me' attitude. Of course the debate on the issue of euthanasiaâboth in the community and in this placeâhas meant that we have focused more on the care of the dying.

I have been moved by the debates on both sides of this argument, but the views put forward by both the honourable member for Bradfield (Dr Nelson) and Senator John Herronâas doctors and as family men who have experienced this on a personal levelâwere to me the most compelling of all. What struck me was their firm belief that death is an important and very moving stage of life and that the strength of human spirit and the wide-ranging emotions experienced by both the patients and their families are vital parts of our rich human tapestry. I recognise that there are many exponents of euthanasia in my electorate, and they have very strong and valid views on this issue, but I do hope that they will agree with me that proper palliative care is a very viable alternative that allows dignity and relief from pain without the notion that life is disposable and without placing an onerous burden on someone who is under great physical and emotional duress.

Many of the horror stories of painful death that are put forward by supporters of euthanasia are cases where proper palliative care had not been available. I understand that there were no palliative care facilities at all in the Northern Territory. I am not saying that palliative care is some sort of panacea for all pain, but it is a way to ensure that dying patients are afforded proper care and pain management.

I think the problem has been that state and federal governments in the past have seen palliative care funding as something of a waste. The aim of medicine after all is to treat, with the ultimate goal of curing the patient. If that cannot be achieved then I think there is a school of thought that says, `Why spend valuable dollars on patients who simply cannot be cured?' But any compassionate society must view palliative care very differently. I wholeheartedly support this motion that we look at providing more funds for palliative care, particularly in people's homes. I was very distressed recently to hear of constituents of mine who would dearly have loved to have their father die in their home but, because of administration problems, they were not afforded that opportunity. I will fight all I can to make sure that that changes in the future.

Our $280 million staying at home package for the care of the frail elderly acknowledges that people prefer to be at home to being at a hospital or institution. That is particularly true of people who are dying. Home is a personal place where they can spend time with their families in familiar surroundings. I note that many palliative care facilities do encourage their patients to spend time at home for short periods but, inevitably, they must return for treatment.

I very much support this motion that we fund a program which allows for full and proper treatment in the patients' homes, providing of course that they have the necessary support and care from their loved ones. It is a commonsense approach that puts the needs of the patient first and will also be considerably less expensive than the high cost involved in the upkeep of a place in hospital. It would be entirely in keeping with our government's practical and innovative approach to so many issues that were simply left in the too-hard basket by the previous government. We have maintained funding for palliative care that was scheduled to finish under Labor and I believe the whole issue of palliative care deserves our close attention. I commend this motion to the house and I am pleased to lend my strong support to the member for Stirling's effort in this important matter.

talk.start.para: âI am pleased to have the opportunity to participate in this important debate proposed by the member for Stirling (Mr Eoin Cameron). Caring for a loved one who is passing through the last stages of life is a time of great stress, emotion and anxiety for everybody that is involved. More people are being provided with health care services in their homes than in hospital or other health care institutions, and this is particularly the case with palliative care. Caring for someone with a terminal illness in their own home makes life just that little bit easier during their remaining time and provides their family with added comfort before their loved one passes on.

speech.para: Palliative care is particularly resource intensive and requires a lot of time and effort by both health care workers and family carers for the person who is dying. Provision of palliative care by community health services tends to be underrecognised compared to the care provided by specialist palliative care teams. By offering palliative care at home, community health services offer an important choice for people who wish to die at home. One such community health service provider that offers this option for palliative care is the New South Wales Community Health Association. They are holding their annual conference in Newcastle on 18 and 19 September this year. The community health care program was initiated by the Whitlam government and we hope that, at that conference, former Prime Minister Gough Whitlam will be able to find the time to address or even just be at the conference to provide encouragement and a morale boost.

One important consideration is the person's choice to have care from non-religious providers, because currently most specialist palliative care is provided by religious organisations and mainly within metropolitan areas. Community health services also increase access to palliative care to more people who are dying and need this care. The Hunter Area Health Service community health division is one local group that offers this option for care in my region. Specialist palliative care services generally provide care only to people who have an identified terminal illness, such as cancer, HIV and AIDS, whereas community health services provide care to any person who wishes to depart this life in their own home. This includes older people who are no longer capable of caring for themselves and who would prefer to stay in their own home rather than go into a nursing home.

I want to see increased funding for palliative care, along with the consideration also of the needs of carers. Carers are absolutely integral to the care of people dying at home. These carers are not eligible for domiciliary nursing care benefits, as this would require the carer to be present 24 hours a day. As families and volunteers often share the palliative care, no one person is present for 24 hours a day. This small payment would make life easier for both the carers and the person receiving the care. Some of the medications required towards the end of the careâfor example, hyoscine, which helps dry up excessive secretions and ensures the comfort of both the person dying and their carersâare very expensive and hence are not in the pharmaceutical benefits scheme.

Care provided at home is an essential part of the overall health service which we provide. It is a cost-effective alternative to care institutions and is preferred by many people who are dying. Because of the intensive nature of the care required, thought must be given to increasing the funding for palliative care, particularly to community health services, to provide this care in partnership with general practitioners and specialist outreach palliative care services.

In the proposed health care agreements, this government claims to be expanding the funding for mental health and palliative care. However, the so-called new money for these services is simply a continuation of existing funding. It is not new funding at all; it is a heartless ruse to claim that it is. The states say that this government's funding offer would result in more than one million extra patients being added to hospital waiting lists and that these waiting lists would prevent the extension of palliative care to people in their homes. Without additional funding for palliative care, those patients with terminal illnesses would not have the alternative of spending their last weeks and days in their own homes with their families and loved ones around them.

What this government has done is to double count the funding for mental health and palliative care. There is $479 million for mental health and palliative care in the current offer that was provided by the Commonwealth but not included in the previous Medicare agreement. Many of my constituents are forced to suffer as a result of the cut to dental services, aged care and the pharmaceutical benefits scheme. But this government still has the audacity to claim that it is offer ing adequate health funding. To decrease rather than increase the funding for palliative care is a heartless move, a move which is causing anguish, pain and suffering to those who desperately need this care. The government should be ensuring that palliative care is extended to as many people as possible in their own homes, people who desperately need this careâpeople with cancer, with HIV or with AIDS and people in the last days of their lives who want to spend the remaining time with their families and friends in the familiar surroundings of their own homes. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âIt gives me much pleasure to rise and support this motion on palliative care. Home is where these people belong. It is where they are able to maintain some degree of control and retain their dignity. It is where intimacy is possible in their communications, their grieving, their expressions of affection and their spiritual activities. Home is where family can stay or come and go, and where loneliness is never a problem for the patient. One does not have to be terminally ill to realise how lonely a hospital can be. When one is suffering from an illness of any sort, hospitals can be very lonely and very unfriendly places.

speech.para: My younger daughter, while nursing in a private hospital in Brisbane during the late 1980s, became aware that many of the patients were admitted to the hospital to die. This worried her for a number of reasons, not the least of which was the lack of time she and the other staff were able to give these patients. She was also concerned with the lack of adequate training in palliative care that they received in connection with cases where more than just good nursing was needed. Also, there was the isolation of the patient from family, friends and neighbours. The hospital staff did what they could but, as my daughter saw it, the situation was barely adequate.

Fortunately, in the last 10 years we have come a long way from those early experiences of that young registered nurse in a medical ward at a private hospital. We now have structured nursing courses in palliative care, as well as many organisations providing professional advice and support for both the patient and his or her carers. Such organisations provide professional expertise in encouraging terminally ill patients to stay at home with their families. Home is the place where these friends and neighbours can provide substantial help and support to both carer and patient.

Two organisations providing dedicated palliative care in my constituency are Karuna and St Luke's Nursing Service. Both have recently told me of stories of families who have had a loved one die in the comfort of their own home. The loss of a loved one, no matter how prepared one is, is a sad time; however, both these accounts tell of the satisfaction of being able to provide the comfort of home to their family member. The family and friends are able to gather for the usual family functions, recognising birthdays and other special occasions, enabling the patient to participate. Not only does home care provide for the patient, but also the comings and goings of the other family members and friends give essential support and comfort to the household.
Bert Errington writes in the Karuna Hospice News:

I find it difficult to write of those weeks that followed the doctor's final sentence. We fought the inevitable, trying alternative medicine, diet and meditation. We decided if we did lose we would not be parted until the end. I did not realise how hard it would be to achieve that unwanted goal. We tried initially to manage by ourselves. Lizzie's mother, her sister-in-law and one of her oldest nursing friends. There were plenty of other volunteers, neighbours and friends who were willing to help. Sometimes embarrassing in their numbers.

It became apparent very quickly that although we had many willing hands, we did not have the necessary skills to keep Lizzie comfortable and in as little pain as possible. The `specialist' had suggested the Karuna Hospice Service for palliative care. When contacted, they responded immediately with advice, nursing aid, overnight care and equipment we had no idea was available. That, one could be forgiven for thinking, was surely more than one could ask for. But I had no way of knowing how dedicated and passionate each new face that came through the door was to be. They were all different shapes and sizes, but they all had big hearts. Without their help we could not have kept Lizzie in the home she loved surrounded by people she cared for most.
Elizabeth died with a wry smile on her face. I like to think she knew something pleasant was waiting on the other side or she was already telling one of her stories to whoever would listen.

Similarly, St Luke's fondly remembers Joseph whom they had been visiting for three months before they received a call at 5 a.m. one morning to tend to him as he had begun to suffer greater pain and discomfort. With his family together in the bedroom and him resting more comfortably, Joseph turned to the St Luke's nurse and said, `I am confident with you here.'

The Howard government recognises the need and the place that palliative care has. Currently the government is working in partnership with Palliative Care Australia, a non-government organisation that provides a national information service and help line. As a result, Dr Wooldridge will release on 13 July a national palliative care strategy which will significantly increase federal funding over the next five years towards improving Australia's palliative care services. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âOrder! The time allotted for this debate has expired. The debate is therefore adjourned, and the resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day for the next sittings.

debate.para: Question proposed:
That grievances be noted.

talk.start.para: âA general grievance from many people in Australia over the last 40 years must surely be the lack of attention to balanced and complete infrastructure spending at all levels of government. I will try to explain what I mean by `complete' a little later.

speech.para: City engineers and state and federal transport ministers have largely suffered in silence, excluded from real power, and been subjected to the `advice'âif you could call it thatâfrom a motley collection of bureaucrats and consultants and plans that somehow did not quite get completed. Take for example the standardisation of Australia's railway track from Brisbane to Perth, celebrated rightfully a couple of years ago. The concept of the transition from the inefficiencies of different gauges to standard gauge was celebrated, as I said, rightfully. But the celebrations are a bit flat really when passenger and freight trains between Melbourne and Adelaide have to slow down to speeds of 20 to 40 kilometres per hour on large sections of track in Victoria. I suspect the train was faster 100 years agoâand I know it was faster 50 years ago.

The Commonwealth standardised the track, which is a good thing, but it did not do it properly. That story, as far as infrastructure is concerned, is repeated ad nauseam all over Australiaâand some people wonder why people have lost faith in the political process. Certainly it is an old cliche, but most people subscribe to the adage that `if you do something, at least do it properly and completely'.

Unfortunately, that does not seem to apply to rail infrastructure in Australia. Successive Australian governments for 80 years have promised to build a railway from Adelaide to Darwin, but still the Alice Springs to Darwin link remains unfinished. The coalition has promised $100 million to the project; the Labor opposition has promised $300 million. The message to politiciansânot just from South Australians and also Territorians in your state, Mr Deputy Speaker, but the wider Australian electorate as wellâis quite simple: build the dammed thing! Have a little faith. It will work. On defence grounds alone, it is justifiable. Get on with it, is the message. Mr Deputy Speaker, I understand that one-third of Australia's population lives in Sydney, Melbourne and Canberra. But why do so many people forget that two-thirds, the overwhelming majority, of Australians do not live there. Some people still do not seem to get the message.

One bright spot, as far as infrastructure expenditure in Australia is concerned, was completed by a Labor government in Western Australiaâand of course I refer to the northern suburbs railway. This is an overwhelming success, and congratulations are due to former ministers Bob Pearce, Julian Grill and Professor Peter Newman. They outfought, outwitted and beat all the knockersâand there were plenty of themâin Canberra, Sydney and Melbourne. But, unfortunately, that example in Western Australia does not fit the general pattern.

The major industrial areas in Adelaide form a semi-circle arc from the Port of Adelaide at Outer Harbour through Port Adelaide, Wingfield, Dry Creek, Regency Park, Salisbury to General Motors-Holden at Elizabeth, taking in two federal Labor electorate seats of Port Adelaide and Bonython and two currently Liberalâprobably next time Laborâseats of Adelaide and Makin. In this area during the last 10 years the federal Labor government, to its credit, completed three major road infrastructure projects. The Port Wakefield highway was duplicated, two lanes each way all the way from Gepps Cross to Port Wakefield; the South Road connector was built in 1994, connecting the Port Wakefield Road to the South Road; and the Salisbury Overway Bridge, connecting all of the above to the Salisbury Highway, was completed in 1996.

They were great projects. Business, manufacturing industry and transport, in particular, increased their efficiency dividend. But the efficiency dividend, although increased, was not maximised. As is so often the case in Australia, one part of this infrastructure to complete what would be one of the best transport hubs in the world let alone Australia was not completed. That partâa state government responsibility but one which needs Commonwealth leadership and some moneyâis the third river opening rail and road crossing. This would connect a dual highway from the Port of Adelaide, Outer Harbour, bypassing the city of Port Adelaide by road and rail to link up with the South Road connector and the Dry Creek rail yards.

The all-up cost is in the vicinity of $60 million to $80 million. Even if it were about $10 million more, it would still be a worthy project. The efficiency dividend for business would be enormous. The transport hub would be outstanding. Access to road, rail, airport and port would be second to none in this country. Sometimes this very fact seems to bring out prospective envy from other states, particularly from that fellow in Victoria called Mr Kennett. This aspect alone would prove very attractive for businesses to locate in my electorate. It is a boost that South Australia desperately needs.

When the federal budget came down in May, one of the things I examined was the roads of national importance program in the Transport and Regional Development portfolio. I understand that the Liberal state minister, Diana Laidlaw, and the Major of Port Adelaide/Enfield, Johanna McCluskey, had lobbied the minister on this particular project, and I was hopeful that a decision would at last be made. What a disappointment. Not only was the third river opening road and rail bridge crossing sadly overlooked but not one dollar of national roads of importance funding was coming to South Australiaânot one measly dollar. Two-thirds of Australia's population live outside Sydney, Melbourne and Canberra, but that very real fact seems to be overlooked by this federal government whilst the state government in South Australia consumes itself with leadership divisions. For the time being, heavy industrialised traffic will continue all so slowly to rumble through the streets of Port Adelaide, inefficiently delivering a dividend in transport, hampering local efforts to breathe life back into the heart of the port and its suburbs and not completing what would be one of the best transport hubs in the world.

For the record, I repeat that South Australia did not receive one dollar from the roads of national importance program. On this particular matter Premier Olsen, his transport minister, Diana Laidlaw, and all the Liberal federal members have so far failed to convince the federal coalition of the most urgent infrastructure needs for South Australia. We did not get two submarines by the way either. It is not only transport and business that would benefit from the third river opening road and rail crossing. Port Adelaide has more historic buildings preserved but not yet fully utilised than any other port city in Australia. It is a gold mine being rediscovered but held back because investors in waterfront housing and development are rightfully deferring investment until they are certain that the third river opening rail and road bridge will go ahead.

Port Adelaide needs a critical mass of some 3,000 to 4,000 people again living within its historic precincts to breathe some life back into its considerable retail, financial, shipping, manufacturing, educational and transport heart. Some 140 houses are currently in the process of being built on the upper reaches of the river. Those developments need to be duplicated over and over again. Wharf shed two has been removed, opening up the soon to be built wharf development at Lipson Street in Port Adelaide.

They are indeed most welcome developments, but they are just a beginning, as were the Port Adelaide TAFE and markets built on the waterfront adjacent to the Birkenhead Bridge, on which heavy truck traffic should be removed and in a time sooner than most imagine will for several reasons have to be closed to heavy traffic. I hope it is not because a disaster occurs. Retail and leisure developments, like movie theatres, restaurants and niche strip shopping, are urgently required on Commercial Road from Dale Street to the Black Diamond Corner to Church Place on St Vincent Street. The third river opening rail and road bridge will be just the catalyst to secure that necessary investment.

I began this speech stating that too often in Australia infrastructure projects are not fully completed, thus minimising the efficiency dividends that I believe taxpayers demand and this country needs. The third river opening road and rail bridge in my electorate of Port Adelaide, affecting the electorates of Bonython, Adelaide, Hindmarsh and Makin, is a prime example of continued partial failures of governments at both the federal and the state levels.

I hope that this government or the nextâhopefully Laborâapplies 20/20 vision, a dose of commonsense and a bit of intellect to this particular matter. If so, then we can look forward to a model transport hub at least being set up in Australia that just might be the appropriate model to transfer something that we can learn to larger hubs in the eastern states. Mr Deputy Speaker Dondas, I remain forever the optimist. However, I do know, as I suspect you do, living in the Northern Territory, that out there in the electorate patience is wearing very thin and infrastructure projects once touted by governments and oppositions alike ought to be completed. One I hope that you would agree with is the Alice Springs-Darwin railway. One for me in my electorate in South Australia and for South Australian industry and manufacturing, in particular, is the third river opening bridge crossing in Port Adelaide. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âIn this debate today I will speak on two issues that are important to my electorate of Eden-Monaro. The first relates to access to SBS television and the second relates to the Eden regional forest agreement. SBS TV, ABC TV, three commercial channels and now pay TV are all services that are taken for granted in city areas and many of the larger regional towns. Today, a petition signed by 1,607 constituents of Eden-Monaro, predominantly from the far South Coast, was tabled here in parliament. That petition called on the government to provide SBS TV to the Bega Valley Shire area.

speech.para: Services to rural and regional areas have been receiving fairly prominent attention in recent times and for good reason. So much that is taken for granted in the larger cities just is not available in rural areas, or if it is people have to travel to access it, or the particular service is of a lower quality or lower frequency. Many services start as a luxury but end up as part of everyday life and SBS has also gone through that transition.

SBS was first provided only in the large cities of Sydney and Melbourne, then progressively went to the other capital cities and regional towns which have a high ethnic population. But the diversity of programs on SBS quickly improved and soon it was sought by all Australians. Prior to the 1996 election the coalition gave a commitment to spend $10.5 million in our first three years to extend SBS to more Australians as part of a commitment to extend it to all Australians. We are meeting that commitment and I emphasise that it is an acceleration of the SBS coverage from that which occurred under the previous government.

For example, in its last four years in government, the Labor Party spent $9.5 million extending SBS. Spending $10.5 million in our first three years is a considerable acceleration. However, that extension has not reached those parts of my electorate currently without SBS and that constitutes a significant area. Only Queanbeyan, Cooma and Berridale have SBS coverage, along with some isolated pockets at the northern end of the coastal part of my electorate.

The petition that I tabled earlier came about as a result of community debate, which also included a public meeting in Merimbula in May. I attended that public meeting, along with some 250 other people who were there to express their support for the extension of SBS. I have great sympathy with these people and the many others in my electorate who cannot access SBS. I feel particularly for those soccer fans who are currently missing out on the World Cup coverage. Only a couple of days ago, I received a letter from young Simon White who wrote:
I am 10 years old and I am interested in the World Cup. Please ask the government to bring SBS to the Bega Valley.
It really is a great shame that some of the commercial television stations which were offered the coverage by SBS did not take that offer up.

We made great headway in improving telecommunications in the last couple of years throughout regional Australia. For instance, all telephone exchanges in New South Wales are now digital. This means easier access to things like fax lines, the Internet, voice mail, et cetera. Networking the Nation is opening up all sorts of possibilities for regional Australia. So, regarding telecommunications, we have done a mountain of work, and there is more to come as we continue to put substantial funds into regional telecommunications infrastructure. We need, similarly, to continue to improve radio and television broadcasting facilities, and that includes SBS.

We have accelerated the extension of SBS since coming to government and, on behalf of all the constituents of Eden-Monaro who do not have access to SBS, I have made a number of representations to the Minister for Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts (Senator Alston) to put our case strongly for a further acceleration of that access so that people in regional Australia have access to SBS just like their city counterparts.

The other matter I want to raise is the regional forest agreement for which submissions closed last Friday on the various scenarios put forward. I prepared a submission commenting on those scenarios which I want to summarise today. First of all, I support the broad principles of the forest policy statement. However, I do have a number of concerns as to how those principles have been put into practice in the process in this Eden RFA. While all of the various studies have been undertaken and therefore, in theory, the processes have followed a scientific approach, the reality is something else. I am particularly concerned that the economic and social assessment studies became almost an afterthought in the process.

While it may be argued that, nonetheless, they were done and have been taken into account, the fact that they were the last cab off the rank has meant that that aspect has played second fiddle to conservation issues in the broader public debate. We should not underestimate the importance of the public debate in this process. We have seen, over the last couple of years, a far greater emphasis on the conservation issues as the various flora and fauna studies were carried out. Meanwhile, economic and social impacts were continually seen as anecdotal as the research had not been done. By the time those studies were done the public debate was already making decisions about the conservation outcomes.

The most serious aspect of the process, which was in fact a breach of the agreed methodology, was the New South Wales government's declaration of national parks part of the way through. That single, politically motivated action undermined the credibility of the process and signalled to the public that the process was not really based on science. The Premier not only pre-empted the final agreement by declaring further national parks but also put pressure on stakeholders that he expected a further 33,000 hectares to be added in the final agreement. No other RFA has been conducted under such intimidation. Effectively, the New South Wales government has limited the debate and, consequently, the general public thinks it is a choice of reserving between 20,000 and 60,000 hectares, depending on the option. The national parks already declared are part of this RFA and should be taken into account in any final agreement.

Scenario A is referred to as the `extreme green option'. This scenario undoubtedly would see the closure of the hardwood industry in the south-east, and along with it would go the communities which rely heavily on it. The Harris-Daishowa woodchip mill has indicated it could close as a result of the implementation of scenario A. Such a result would mean the loss of 500 direct jobs and probably a further 500 jobs indirectly. Scenario A really has to be rejected outright. It does not follow science; it includes areas in Coolangubra, for instance, which did not meet the flora criteria. So it cannot be considered at all.

Scenario B is a scenario put forward by the New South Wales government. It increases sawlog quotas slightly and pulpwood quotas slightly but, once again, would see the demise of the hardwood industry and along with it its communities. This scenario also includes this area of Coolangubra and does not meet the criteria put forward in fact by National Parks and Wildlife, which are now promoting this option. It is not a true balance and it also should be rejected. Scenario C has been put forward by part of the industry. There are some participants in the industry who do not actually fully support it. It provides 26,000 cubic metres of sawlogs, but unfortunately it relies upon changes in management protocols to get that 26,000. I see 26,000 as the minimum required to maintain jobs in the area. It is not guaranteed and I do not think those protocols would be changed.

Scenario D, as put forward by the Commonwealth, would guarantee 26,000 cubic metres of sawlogs and 363,000 tonnes of pulpwood, based on current conservation protocols. It would give that least number of sawlog quotas necessary to maintain the existing jobs. I believe that there is a justifiable argument for 29,500. That is what was guaranteed originally by the New South Wales government verbally and ultimately in writing as well. Scenario D is the minimum that we need and that is what I am putting forward. Prior to the 1995-96 interim forest agreement, the sawlog quota for Eden was 59,000 cubic metres, so you can see how much we have come down. We need to maintain those jobs.

In the view of large numbers of my constituents, the hardwood industry and the communities that rely on it have suffered unfairly in the ideological battle that has taken place over the last decade. The pendulum has swung too far and it is time that the social impact was given a higher priority. I urge both governments to have a scenario which meets this level of 29,500 cubic metres. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âI grieve today for the vast majority of Australians, who are suffering under what can only be described as the heartless indifference of this government towards the Australian community. The Australian community does feel betrayed by a government which promised so much: it promised to be a government for all of us; it promised to make us all feel relaxed and comfortable, yet neither of those things have occurred. As I move about the electorate, especially with my Saturday morning mobile offices, no-one comes to me and says they feel relaxed and comfortable. They have only to look at the track record of this government to see the damage that has been done to this community over the last 2Â¼ years.

speech.para: Without seeking to score a political point, I would endorse the comments attributed to my colleague on the other side the member for Dunkley, Bruce Billson, who I believe did speak for all of us when, as reported in the Age of 24 June last week, he said to his party room meeting the day before that the government should `stand up for suburban Australia'. I would endorse those sentiments, having the privilege of representing an electorate of similar location and similar demographics to Dunkley. It is somewhat heartening for me to realise that not all coalition members adhere to what can only be described as the scorched earth policy of the front bench opposite, polices which are so easily pursued by Mr Billson's government in general.

Again, as I do move around I find there are some recurring issues: health, unemployment, education and child care. People increasingly, as they become more and more economically literate, are beginning to understand the economic fundamentals which plague this nation. They do realise that it is in fact the current account, in addition to many of the issues I have just cited, which is of paramount importance to their living standards and the maintenance of those standards. That is what is confronting the government today.

This current account is expected to blow out from some $18 billion in 1996-97 to $31 billion in 1998-99. Under attack, largely from foreign speculators, the Australian dollar can at best be described as precariously poised. Our consumption spending is growing faster than national production. Indeed, we see the growth of private investment dropping and the ratio of household savings to household disposable incomes falling from 4.7 per cent in 1996-97 to an estimated 2.8 per cent in 1998-99. I have quoted those figures from a recent article in the Age by Kenneth Davidson.

Yet it seems that all this government is hell-bent on doing is talking about how its surpluses may be available for some future reduction in the tax rate; that is, a tax cut. It is really as if the budget deficits of more than 10 years ago wereâas Davidson would sayâthe cause rather than the consequence of the 1991 recession. Most economists would tell you that if the budget deficit did not blow out during recessionary times, thereby stimulating the economy by pumping more money into it, as a natural corollary any recession under those circumstances would indeed be exacerbated and be far worse because without these what automatic stabilisers, as I have called them before, built into budgets then in what Davidson has described as advanced industrial countries in the post-World War II era the recessions of the early 1980s and 1990s could have become economic disasters, indeed on the scale of the 1930s Great Depression.

The serious issue confronting Australians today is not the budget deficit but plainly the current account. This is exacerbated in both the East Asian bloc and in our own nation by the huge volume of speculative capital that seems to circulate endlessly around the globe. If Australia is about to go into a recessionâor perhaps even far worseâit is likely to emerge from the exposure to foreign speculation due to reliance on the foreign debt to finance this current account deficit rather than any difficulties with financing the budget. That is something that the Prime Minister, Mr Howard, has to acknowledge and acknowledge pretty quickly because it is those reasons of financial mismanagement, despite inheriting a economy which he described as better than good in partsâa high growth, low inflation economyâthat are causing the average Australians whom I am meeting in the streets, mostly on Saturday mornings, considerable pain.

My electorate of Isaacs has the highest number of children under four in child care in any electorate in this country. This is an area where this government has again failed to make this community relaxed and comfortable, because it has managed to cut some $1 billion from child-care funding. No amount of money that it has attempted to put back into child care in this most recent budget has gone anywhere near making up for the cuts that it inflicted on the electorate in its first two budgets. This has forced many children to be withdrawn from child care, placing the welfare of children at risk. It has forced many parents, mostly mothers, out of the work force because they are simply unable to afford decent quality child care.

One could go on to speak about education. Similarly, as with child care, the government has ripped the heart out of education. Nationally, our respected and beloved TAFE system has endured a $240 million cut. Similarly, Austudy has been slashed by some $500 million.

talk.start.para: âYou're making all this up. It's not right.
âGovernment schools have had funding cuts of up to $270 million.
âFalse!

âHECS has cost tertiary students around $1.1 million. This government and Minister Kemp, who has deluded the Minister for Customs and Consumer Affairs, who is at the table, and others on his frontbench by saying he tells the truth when he does not, would like to take this education system back to the bad old days when one's level of education was determined primarily by the level of one's personal wealth. Similarlyâand I will conclude on this pointâthe government has let down our unemployed.
âIt had better be good!

âThere is nothing good, Minister, about the level of unemployment in this country. In this government's first 26 months it presided over the creation of a mere 235,000 jobs, which is less than half the number of jobs that Labor had created in the same period before leaving office. In Labor's last 26 months of governmentâand the figures stand right there, issued by DEETYAâLabor created 549,000 jobs and the unemployment rate trend at that time was down by 2.2 per cent. One is reluctant somewhat to compare that with the current government that could achieve a trend in the unemployment rateâan important statisticsâthat was down by only 0.5 per cent.

speech.para: We have seen local unemployment in most parts of Isaacs rising sharply in the past two years. With the unemployment levels yet to bottom due to the impact of the Asian crisis, one can only despair for the unemployed in Isaacs and the other 147 electorates in the country, as indeed we despair for the many Australians who at the hands of this government are faced with child-care, education, aged care and health cuts of a magnitude rarely seen in this country.

talk.start.para: âI grieve for the people surrounding the Perth airport who are being treated as political pawns by the Labor Party and their apparatchiks. The Perth airport is again in the news today because the Perth airport's draft master plan is to be presented to the Minister for Transport and Regional Development (Mr Vaile) on 1 July, this Wednesday. It is not the first time that the Perth airport has been in the news.

speech.para: One funny thing that strikes me at the moment is that the Labor Party have suddenly got interested in the Perth airport again. While they were in government for 13 years they pretended it was not there. In fact, the member for Brand (Mr Beazley), the former member for Swan, did all he could to play down any acknowledgment of the Perth airport and its effect on some of the surrounding residents. I was privileged to be a member of the planning committee of the City of Belmont, which largely houses the Perth airport. When Mr Beazley was the then minister, he came to the City of Belmont and was very keen to off-load the Perth airport and, to sweeten the deal, offered to throw in a couple of million dollars to get rid of Jandakot airport. That was their attitude to the airports at that stage. I can assure you that that can be verified.

The main reason for the grievance today relates to the current draft plan. We do note that the Perth airport was sold on a long-term lease to the current owners of the airport, the Westralia Airports Corporation, who paid $600-odd million for the airport. But the politicisation of the airport by people with obvious agendas has caused there to be many submissions, and these have been based on incorrect assumptions.

For the people present in the House, I would like to hold up a map of the details of the existing noise contours surrounding Perth airport. Mr Deputy Speaker, if you could actually see from where you are the flights paths that emanate from the 06/24 runway on this mapâI have my suspicions as to who put this map out, by the wayâyou would see that it is a child's drawing. The flight paths are not practical. In fact, it has been said by those who know about planes and airports that one would have to be flying an FA18 to achieve some of the flight paths that have been described here. This map was abjectly put out to try to scare the people surrounding the Perth airport. Other anonymous letters have gone out. The one I am holding up now has `sold out' written over it. It raises a number of issues. It is signed by `A concerned resident'. They would not put their name to it. This is politicisation of the issues surrounding the Perth airport.

I specifically want to address some of the measures involved in the draft master plan. Probably the most contentious of these is the proposal in the draft master plan to extend the 06/24 runway which runs south-east. It is a shorter runway, but Airservices Australia inform me that 747s could, under most conditions, land on this runway, as could the A320 Airbuses that are most commonly used. There seems very little justification for the extension of this runway. I am on the record as saying I do not believe it is appropriate. In fact, rather than building an extension to the 06/24 runway, the parallel runway should be proceeded with forthwith. This would take away the need to build an extension to the 06/24 runway.

Yesterday, the member for Perth (Mr Stephen Smith) and his sidekick, the Mayor of Bayswater, John D'Orazio, held a press conference with the Westralia Airports Corporation. They were pleased to have this joint press conference. There has been a complete turnaround by the member for Perth and his offsider, the Mayor of Bayswater. The Mayor of Bayswater was, by the way, the unsuccessful Labor candidate for the seat of Ballajura in the last election. That tells a little story, but the point is that these people have tried to engineer some thousands of standard letter responses against the extension of the 06/24 runway. Yesterday, with the Westralia Airports Corporation, they came out and endorsed it. My point is that they have sold out the rest of the shires and the interest groups around the Perth airport. The City of Belmont is alarmed by the sell-out that has happened.

The City of Belmont also helped engineer many transcripts and standard letters to gain community support for the non-extension of this runway. These people were not consulted before this press conference. John D'Orazio is the chair of the Perth Airport Municipalities Group. He certainly did not get the endorsement of that group to make this announcement. The Shire of Kalamunda and the affected people in South Perth and Mundaring were not consulted. No-one else was consulted. There is a craven political stunt by those involved.

I want to point out an article by Torrance Mendez which appears in the West Australian newspaper with the headline `Protesters stop runway plan'. At their press conference, the member for Perth and Mr D'Orazio came out with some absolutely farcical reasons as to why they now support the extension of the runway. The article quotes Mr Smith and Mr D'Orazio as saying that if four points are written into the master planâI will address them as we goâthey will then throw their weight behind the extension of the runway. All four points that they mention are currently in existence.

The point that has to be made is that the inclusion of these measures in the draft master plan does not in any way guarantee the success of this runway. I was informed by the minister's office as recently as several minutes before I came into this chamber that the minister's approval of the draft master plan is not contingent on details like whether these people want to put conditions on the extension of the runway. The minister will either approve the runway or he will not. The details addressed by this lobby group might not be endorsed by another group. The minister has to take into account all the other people who have an interest in this matter. I want to address a couple of these points. The article in the West Australian says:
Mr Smith said the potential for noisy flight paths over several suburbs unaffected by the noise had been eliminated.
That is not true. Noise cannot be eliminated. When people live near an airport they are going to have noise, to some extent.
Mr Smith also said:
Restrictions on usage will be a condition for approving the extension.

As I have said, that is not true. The minister does not do it that way. The minister will not grant approval for master plans on the basis of some deal that is made on the side with one of the local councils. The article goes on to say:
Draft measures and restrictions include:
. Takeoffs and landings from the south-west on the extended runway 06/24 would only occur in emergencies, extreme weather or when the main runway was unavailable.

That happens now. In fact, that situation is monitored by Airservices Australia. It happens now. It will happen well into the future. That is the way the airport is managed. That point does not need to be put into the draft master plan to be a bargaining chip. The article goes on to say:
. Current approach and take-off paths for jet aircraft would be maintained.
Ballyhoo! What does that mean? That is happening now. What is new about that? The article also says:
. Take-offs and approach noise abatement procedures would be reviewed.
The procedures are reviewed all the time to make sure that there is less of an impact on people. The article continues:
. Aerodrome information referred to by commercial pilots would be updated to include the restrictions.

I am sure aerodrome information for commercial pilots approaching Perth airport is continually updated. It is just a load of fatuous nonsense to say that these people have been involved in some sort of deal to achieve the extension of this runway. The article also says:
Mr Smith acknowledged that runway 06/24 had existing noise restrictions but said they did not go far enough to address local residents' concerns

They do not. What really has to be addressed is what I am trying to achieve for the Perth airportâand I believe I am getting closer all the timeâand that is a noise amelioration package for the affected houses in the area on the same basis as the noise amelioration package given to Sydney airport. Under these conditions it would be a fair transfer of the conditions.

In conclusion, the whole basis of these proposals is nonsense. It is misleading people. It is using them as political pawns. I believe that the consultation period has been a good one. But, in the end, the parallel runway is the option, not the extension of the 06/24 runway. I do not know the reason for this tawdry deal, but this turnaround leaves open to question the motives of these people.

talk.start.para: âOne of the abuses of our subsidised health care system is the practice known as `doctor shopping'. It arises when an individual goes not necessarily to a large number, but usually a large number, of medical practitioners seeking prescriptions for a particular drug or drugs. At the outset I want to mention that we have been assured by the Minister for Health and Family Services (Dr Wooldridge) that a person who sees 30 different prescribing doctors in a single 12-month period is likely to come under scrutiny by the Health Insurance Commission, the HIC, as a possibleâand I would suggest a probableâ`doctor shopper'.

speech.para: Apparently, the people who engage in this practice do so for one of several reasons. Most commonly, doctor shoppers are people who are trying to obtain narcotics or benzodiazepines such as Rohypnol, valium and Temazepam, pharmaceuticals of dependence of one sort or another, to feed a drug habit. A medical practitioner who is a constituent of mine says that such patients are also abusing the codeine containing medications such as Codral and Panadeine Forte in between narcotic drug use.

In other cases, doctor shoppers are people who collect a large range of government subsidised pharmaceuticals to take overseas and sell on the black market. There is more than anecdotal evidence that the system is being defrauded by some people who acquire large quantities of prescription drugs in Australia through doctor shopping and sell them at a substantial premium in other parts of the world, more often than not in Third World countries.

The concerns arising from all this are several. First, there is the damage to the health of patients who take an excessive amount of medication or unnecessary medication in order to feed an addiction. Second, regardless of the reason for the doctor shopping behaviour, the taxpayer is being forced to subsidise through the pharmaceutical benefits scheme, the PBS, abusive and fraudulent practices. I understand that the government has been unable to accurately assess the actual cost of this to the taxpayer.

The Health Insurance Commission General Manager of the Professional Review Division, Mr Ralph Watzlaff, testified before the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Family and Community Affairs in 1996. In the context of that committee's concession card inquiry he testified that it is hard to draw a line on one side of which are people who have seen several doctors and who have a genuine medical need for substantial amounts of medication and on the other side of which are people who are doctor shopping. Consequently, the HIC had not reached the stage of putting a figure on the cost involved. Mr Watzlaff told the House of Representatives committee about the strategies deployed by the HIC to identify abuses of the pharmaceutical benefits scheme.

The HIC has two audit processes, one random and the other purpose based. The former looks at a random selection of claims and gives an idea of the extent of fraud on the system in general. Over the two years prior to September 1996 the level of fraud and abuse was less than two per cent. The purpose based audit process identifies areas of potential abuse specifically within the context of the pharmaceutical benefits scheme. Mr Watzlaff told the commission that the HIC did a minor pilot study in 1995 looking at people who had seen more than 30 doctors in one year. He made the point, however, that a person can be a doctor shopper even if he or she is seeing much fewer than 30 doctors a year.

The audit revealed that there was a large amount of drug hoarding. Mr Watzlaff told the committee that the HIC strategy was to intervene and counsel the person and that was successful in a large number of cases. He said that the cost of each intervention was about $300 but that the saving in terms of reduced claims was about $2,500 in each case. Where counselling failed, the HIC has recourse to prosecution. Within the 12 months to September 1996, six people were prosecuted on the basis that they made false representations about their own state of health. Some of those people had been prosecuted several times already.

How is the problem to be solved? One method to tackle the problem has been suggested to the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Family and Community Affairs in the context of its reference on health information management and telemedicine. Mr William Dollman, director of the pharmacy networking project and manager of the drugs and poison section at the South Australian Health Commission, spoke of the need for a common drug history to be recorded for each patient. He claimed that the improvements in technology mean that this will soon be possible.

Mr Dollman contemplated a system whereby drug information can be centralised so that Dr C knows what Dr A and Dr B prescribe for a particular patient so that patients can be prevented from shopping around. Under this proposal it would need to be mandatory for the patient to produce a card at each consultation and the medical practitioner would need to have access to the patient's drug history. While Mr Dollman recognised, as indeed do I, that there are privacy and data integrity issues, he told the standing committee that `the technology is there to overcome all of those things'. I doubt the need to involve the doctors in the process, and I will get to that later, I hope. Ms Jacquelyn Wood, the general manager of the HIC's Government Programs Division, endorsed the model proposed by Mr Dollman. Ms Wood said that the centralised records systems must be fully interactive and computerised, with access to doctors and pharmacies. I doubt that you need to involve doctors in the process, and that is the point I will hopefully make later.

People under the HIC scheme would have the freedom to move from doctor to doctor as they wished, but the doctor would be able to bring up their medical history and obtain information regarding the medication they have been prescribed. That would allow a patient who wishes, for legitimate reasons, to change doctors the freedom of choice to do so and it also detects doctor shopping offenders.

The doctor constituent of mine to whom I referred earlier has suggested an alternative model to avoid the abuse of prescription drugs through doctor shopping. This GP suggests that the drugs most commonly sought by doctor shoppers should be made available only through the authority prescription system that is already in place. Currently doctors have to phone the HIC to obtain approval to prescribe certain medications. My constituent recommends that the authority system be modified so that a patient can obtain no more than one month's supply of benzodiazepines or codeine drugs in any one calendar year on an ordinary prescription. Any amount above that would not be dispensed unless an authority could be obtained. The authority would be structured so that the patient must nominate who the prescribing doctor will be and then must stay with this doctor for future authority prescriptions of the drugs for the rest of any one calendar year. The doctor would be able to prescribe therapeutic quantities only.

If a patient wished to change doctors, the new doctor would replace the original doctor as the doctor nominated for that patient. Any further authority prescriptions of the drugs written by the first doctor for the patients would be invalid. Patients who continually change doctors would also be counselled.

Under this model pharmacists could utilise existing computer link-ups with the HIC authority database and so would not dispense drugs on authority scripts from doctors who are not nominated. Also, it would not routinely involve doctors in the policing network, as would the HIC proposal. However, there is clearly a variety of approaches that may be taken to tackle the problem of patients who doctor shop. It will be useful in the whole exercise to know what a final estimated cost of the practice is. We look forward to the time when the minister can provide that information on behalf of the government. In the meantime there are measures that can be taken. (Time expired).

subdebateinfo.title: Electorate of Mallee: Effectiveness of Federal Member

talk.start.para: âI am pleased to rise immediately following the contribution of the member for Curtin (Mr Rocher) because I am the chairman of the standing committee that prepared that report and four others, including one tabled this very day, which I would like to speak to later. I would like that put formally on the record and advise other members that I have been involved in that since I became a member in March 1993. At the moment there are people running around my electorate saying that I am not a very effective member. I find that a most grievous accusation.

speech.para: It is a pity that the Hansard process does not allow diagrams to be recorded, but I hold in my handâas the first of my success storiesâa diagram of the analog mobile phone network prior to my entry into parliament in 1993. It shows a small circle around the district of Sunraysia, another small circle around the district of Swan Hill, another one around St Arnaud and a little bit along the Western Highway. After a private member's bill in this parliament from the opposition in 1994, I am pleased that today I hold in my hand the digital mobile phone network for the Wimmera-Mallee area. There are 21 mobile telephone digital transponders in locations in places as geographically diverse as Mildura, Red Cliffs, Robinvale, Ouyen, Sea Lake, Swan Hill, Birchip, Wycheproof, Charlton, St Arnaud, Donald, Warracknabeal, Dimboola, Nhill, Lawloit, Lillimur, Mount Arapalies, Horsham, Glencoe, Dadswells Bridge and Mount Zero. I am immensely proud of my record and I find it offensive that people are running around my electorate today saying that I am an ineffective member of parliament.

In addition to that, when I entered the parliament in 1993 I discovered the lament able situation that a district the size of Sunraysia had only two broadcast television channels covering a 50-kilometre radius. You could get a commercial channel and an ABC channel. There was a community operated SBS, but only one commercial TV channel. In March 1993 I committed myself to deliver to that community access to additional television service.
