It was not an easy task way back then and from opposition to take on the Australian Broadcasting Authority to advance the roll-out of consideration, even indeed to take on the network that had the solus control of the existing commercial television channel. I am proud today to say that I delivered. And I am offended that people would run around saying that I am not an effective member. It is true that the community would like to have seen a complete roll-out of the full broadscale services in other parts of the country, but there are some constraints.

Now we have FM radio broadcasting coming out our ears. It amazes me that people want access to so many channels, but we now have three commercial FM channels, Triple J on the ABC and two community radio stations, in Horsham and Sunraysia. Madam Deputy Speaker Kelly, as a local member yourself, you know how much work in the background it takes to put the arguments to the authorities that control the regulation of radio broadcasting. I am proud of it.

As regards telecommunications since then, funding under the regional telecommunications infrastructure fund has been allocated to determine the ongoing requirements and the needs of the strong communities around the Wimmera and the northern Mallee. I am proud of my record.

Environment: $7 million of funding has been allocated already under the Natural Heritage Trust to the Wimmera-Mallee. There is infrastructure like the northern Mallee pipeline, which is a scheme that only the member for Mallee understands. It is a large channel system supplying stock and domestic water all the way from the Grampian Mountains. For 50 years we have been arguing to have this open channel system piped because 90 per cent of the water that leaves the Grampian Mountains does not get to its end destination: some of evaporates but the great bulk of it disappears into the groundwater, creating massive salinity problems. I am proud of my recordâeven from oppositionâand I acknowledge the commitment of the previous government to the first three stages. Subsequent to that there is now a commitment to the fourth stage, with three to go, and I am confident that I can continue to win the arguments to fund that very necessary environment and water use program.

Green Corps: there are already five programs across the Wimmera-Mallee involving young people. It is lifting their expectations of the career path they could have in the environment. One of the projects is preserving the interests of the mallee fowl. I know the member for Franklin (Mr Quick), who was born and raised in the Rainbow district, understands the importance of that little bird as an icon to the arid regions of the Mallee.

Aged care: there have been massive injections into aged care in capital funding. I am proud to see the construction of the Oasis aged care centre at Irymple, and I understand it will be opened very soon. There is the Nyah Bush Nursing Hospital Hostel, the Edenhope Nursing Home and Hostel, the Nhill Aged Care Hostel and many others. It is true that aged care is a massive and significant issue to the isolated communities of the Wimmera-Mallee and that there is a lot more to be done, but I am proud of what has been achieved to date.

Health: there are 10 electronic Medicare lodgment facilities in the isolated communities of the Wimmera-Mallee. As well as all of this local work in arguing this policy implementation through with the bureaucracy and winning those arguments, I am proud of my commitment to this parliament and the duties I have undertaken, particularly as chairman of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Family and Community Affairs: five reports, and another opportunity that members get to advocate strongly for their electorates.

One of those reports on telemedicine, which the member for Curtin has made reference to, provides a wonderful opportunity to deliver real time health care facilities to isolated regions of Australia. Like the member for Curtin, I am awaiting the government's response to that report and some of the others that the committee has tabled.

Further in respect of health, being the federal member requires you to work closely with your state colleagues. The federal electorate of Mallee overlaps the electorates of nine other state members whom I work very closely with. I am proud to say that, working together, we have been able to construct a new hospital at Horshamâand a world class hospital at that. A new hospital is currently being developed at Wycheproof; it is currently out to tender. There is a new hospital on the planning board at Mildura; it is the same situation at Robinvale; there is an upgrade of the Swan Hill Base Hospital; and there is the other work with the health services, including the Mallee Track and the west Wimmera health serviceâso there are so many things I am proud of.

Road funding: the Commonwealth, since the 1996 budget, has spent $34 million on roads in the Wimmera-Mallee and another million dollars on black spot programs, so I am particularly offended to read in the newspaper comments by somebody who has no idea of the amount of work that I have done that I am not a very effective member.

I allude obviously to a pretending candidate from Pauline Hanson's One Nation Party. I will not have that criticism. I will have a debate with respect to policyâlet us have an honest debateâbut no-one can accuse the federal member for Mallee of being lazy or lacking integrity. I will not have it.

I am particularly worked up about this. I have watched very carefully what has happened in Queensland and other places, and I am offended that Australians would propose that we move away from our egalitarian society in which we embrace everybody. Everybody is treated as an equal. I am offended by that very principle and I am not prepared to compromise my principles on that aspect. Under no circumstances will I recommend to the people of Wimmera-Mallee that they put a preference in respect of that outfit any higher than last.

I would ask not just the people of Wimmera-Mallee but the people of Australia to look beyond the wide-eyed innocence of the member for Oxley (Ms Hanson). Probably in her heart of hearts she wants to do exactly what I doârepresent her peopleâbut I do not think she is astute enough to realise how she is being manipulated by unscrupulous elementsâmore particularly, extreme elementsâand I defend my intention to recommend to my electorate that she be placed last. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âI would like to compliment the honourable member for Mallee (Mr Forrest), who I know does a fantastic job for the people in his electorate. I know of the responsibility he takes for the people and the wonderful work he does in looking after my mother, who lives in Nhill.

speech.para: One assumes, all things being equal, that there is a distinct possibility that this will be my last opportunity to participate, at least in this parliament, in the grievance debate. Consequently, I would like to take this opportunity to raise an issue which highlights one of the reasons why our constituentsâand I say `our' advisedlyâare feeling peeved, disenfranchised and are looking to other parties for simple solutions to very complex problems.

I want to read from a letter my electorate office has received recently. It concerns a problem that I am sure many in this House, through their electorate offices, are receiving similar correspondence on. This is the hoary issue of the seeming ineffectiveness of the Child Support Agency to deal with situations like the one I am raising here today. The letter reads:
Re: Poverty and Maintenance of Australia's children
I wish to draw your attention to the inadequacy and injustice of the provisions of the law relating to the payment of maintenance by non-custodial parents.
Basically I feel that the method of assessment for maintenance is completely outdated and leaves many of Australia's sole parents out in the cold.
I see the following problems:

1. The assessment process looks at the taxable income of the non-custodial parent for the two years prior to the assessment dateâwhich never has provided an accurate basis in the present volatile employment environment.

2. Should the non-custodial parent become unemployed, any previous assessment for maintenance reverts to a nil obligation. There is no immediate reassessment upon re-entering the workforce. This is regardless of how short a period the non-custodial parent is unemployed.

3. Should the non-custodial parent choose not to inform the Child Review Office or custodial parent of their new employment circumstances, there is no prescribed penalty, and it is left to the custodial parent to determine all the details at their own expense.

My name is Louise Bloomfield and I am a single mother with an 18-month-old daughter. I am trying to survive financially on the Parenting Payment and any casual work I can find. I am also trying to get child support maintenance from my daughter's father, Mr Alex Kharnam. The way the system works, I have almost no chance of getting him to `do the right thing'.

Let's examine my first point, the two years prior ruling. While determining the taxable income for two years prior may be well and good for those non-custodial parents who have a steady job and careerâthis in no way applies to the majority of working people. It is very common these days for people to change jobs, find themselves out of work for a short time, and all within a matter of months. I feel that an examination of the type of employment that an individual obtains would be an improvement. The non-custodial parent may be unemployed on a seasonal basis, or may regularly be taking up short term contracts (quite the norm these days).

To consider my second point, that short-term unemployment status wipes out any obligation to provide maintenance, I agree that surviving on unemployment benefits is difficult and thus obligation to provide maintenance should be waived AT THAT TIME. But there is no automatic reassessment of income once the non-custodial parent re-enters the workforce. This is a loophole, which is open to abuse.

My child's father has managed to do just that. Once the maintenance assessment has been carried out, all he has to do is walk into the child support agencyâdeclare himself unemployed and the maintenance assessment becomes null and void. Even if he gets work the very next day, the maintenance assessment will not reactivate. The only time his new earnings are reassessed is two years later, at which point all he has to do is become unem ployed for another week and have the obligation nullified yet again.

The third point is the one that I find most frustrating and insidious. Should the non-custodial parent not inform the Child Review Board or the other parent of their better circumstances, then there is no penalty, and no way in which the information can be obtained. I understood that tax file numbers were used to examine the non-custodial parent's income at tax return time, but apparently this is not the case.

I have spent a fair amount of time on the telephone to my daughter's father, hoping that he would provide some information about his present employer. So far I have managed to find that he is employed by "Mine Side Personnel". Finally (courtesy of Telstraânot even Centrelink could give me details of an employer of such a name even though he was employed through them!) I was able to find a corresponding telephone number in Kalgoorlie WA. Even with this information, my Review Officer was unable to provide more than a slim chance that his employer would cooperate.

So how does a non-custodial parent who does not want to pay maintenance get out of it? Quite simply by doing nothing and preferably by being in another state where the custodial parent would find it difficult to find anything out personally. At this point I feel that the rules and regulations regarding maintenance by non-custodial parents are a toothless tiger, and are not to be taken seriously.

I know I may not have explained all that clearly, but I can tell you it makes my blood boil when I get a phone call from my daughter's father in Western Australia to tell me that he is now earning $70 000 to $90 000 per annum and how he doesn't intend to pay maintenance due to the fact that he will become `unemployed ` for a week or so in two years time and so nullify any assessment outcome.

When I tried to get a reassessment, the Review Officer informed me that I had to let them know where and for whom he was working. Now I `think' I may know this time, but what if he doesn't tell me next time? Where does that leave me? Not all non-custodial parents communicate and thus I expect that there are many others in an even worse position than myself.

I would not object so much about this situation if my daughter's father earned $20 000 or $30 000 per annum. But his earning $70 or $80 000 while my daughter and I exist on something just on the poverty line is extremely unfair. It is especially unjust when there is no apparent legal recourse available.

What do I suggest would be a better solution? I think that a direct link between the Child Review Board and the Taxation Office using tax file numbers and an assessment for maintenance based on the present year's taxable income would be one solution. Certainly, the current working environment of inconsistent employment patterns should be considered the norm.

Another improvement could be to reactivate the assessment obligation at any point in time that the paying parent resumes work after being unemployed, ie when the tax office receives a Tax Declaration Form. Also, the introduction of penalties for non-custodial parents and their employers who fail to notify the Child Review Board of their employment circumstances would give teeth to the tiger.

I hope that all of the above made some sense to you. I have had no problem talking and dealing with the Department from Assessment and Child Support Agency. Their people have been very helpful and friendly, but it must be difficult to run such a system when it has no real muscle to deal with people who wish to be unscrupulous.
Yours Sincerely
Louise Bloomfield.

This letter was sent to the minister responsible in anticipation of receiving a learned response to her obvious concerns. What response has there been from the federal minister responsible for this issue? None. This woman has to do much of the ferreting out of information at great cost to herself. STD telephone calls to Kalgoorlie while on the edge of poverty test her finances greatly. And all this to simply attempt to gain justice for herself and her young daughter.

The system, which sent confidential letters to the ex-husband's employers, is so flawed that the contents of these supposedly confidential letters were discussed with him by his employers. He has obviously realised that some pressure, albeit obviously ineffectual pressure at this stage, is to be placed upon him. Out of the blue, Louise receives a cheque for $500, followed by a phone call from her daughter's father to say that he is earning big money in Kalgoorlie.

Has our child support system degenerated to the stage where this woman has to travel to Western Australia at her own expense, drag out the evidence and place it before someone in the agency before those operating in the Hobart and Perth offices remedy this injustice and inequality? I realise that changes have been mooted which go some way to remedying some concerns about the agency, but I urge the minister responsible to undertake to get a serious response from the agency as soon as possible for Ms Bloomfield, so that she can resume her own life, free from hassles and debt not of her own making.

subdebateinfo.title: Hunter Region: Safety, Security and Stability

talk.start.para: âLast Friday afternoon, on ABC Radio in Newcastle, the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Beazley) was caught uttering words of comfort to the people of the Hunter. He told the listeners that what he wanted to see was for security to return and for certainty to prevail. That is a very interesting admission from a man who leads a party that in recent weeks has been mocking members of the current government for daring to spruik such sentiments. Clearly, in the current evolutionaryâsome would say revolutionaryâpolitical landscape now upon us, the Labor Party has not learnt the new ground rules of politics: it no longer pays to say one thing to one audience and do something completely different in front of another.

speech.para: Within a region such as the Hunter, which I have sought to represent with real determination as the coalition's sole lower house member over the past 2Â½ years, the issues of safety, stability and security to enshrine confidence are built very much on the back of local employment growth in a rapidly changing economy. Despite some hiccupsâthe most publicised, of course, being BHP's decision to cease integrated steel making operations at its Newcastle steelworks by the end of 1999âthe region is more than holding the line in the employment stakes. The Hunter Valley Research Foundation confirmed that 10,000 new jobs were created in the Hunter in 1997, at a jobs growth rate of five per centâastoundingly, 12 times the New South Wales average.

The Hunter regional business activity during the last quarter of 1997 registered growth levels of 10 per cent. Whilst acknowledging that the latest economic regionalism report showed that average employment rates have fallen in the six months to March by around 3,000 people, with factors of the Asian economic meltdown starting to hit home, a couple of political soap operas now being played out behind closed doors could in an instant help alter the situation.

One prime issue is that of Redbank power station. The New South Wales Carr Labor government and its corporatised electricity operative, Energy Australia, are playing a very serious and a very dangerous game over Redbank's future. In fact, I take it a step further. What we have over Redbank is the Carr government prepared to spend hundreds of millions of taxpayers' dollars to keep hundreds upon hundreds of Hunter workers out of a job. I say this because proceedings have been set for a full hearing in the Commercial Division of the Supreme Court of New South Wales next Monday, 6 July, in an attempt to prove that Energy Australia has liability over its broken 35-year contract deal with National Power.

National Power, as developers of the groundbreaking Redbank power station, would have employed around 1,450 people in the Hunter in its construction phase and final completion, and they are just the direct jobs. If liability is proven, we go into legal damages and the New South Wales taxpayer will be forced to foot the billâand the jobs and the Redbank power project will be gone forever. The cost will no doubt be in the hundreds of millions of dollars if damages are ultimately granted.

talk.start.para: âOrder! I would remind the honourable member for Paterson that he should not reflect on matters that are sub judice.

âThank you, Madam Deputy Speaker. What a ludicrous position Premier Bob Carr, Treasurer Michael Egan and Energy Minister Bob Debus have put the people of the Hunter inâlet alone the state taxpayers. It is a further rendition of Bob Carr's employment waltz for the people of the Hunter; that is, the federal government takes us two steps forward and then the state Labor government takes us one step back when it comes to job creation. The whole affair is on the verge of being a complete, unmitigated disaster for Hunter taxpayers and Hunter workers. To question this statement only ignores what Bob Debus and his office have said on the public record. I quote from the Newcastle Herald of 1 April over the National Power-Energy Australia impasse:

speech.para: The wrangle was an issue between Energy Australia and National Power, and the Government did not wish to intervene.
This is a disgraceful stance from the minister for electricity in New South Wales. The same tone is exhibited by Messrs Egan and Carr.

Within this House we have the likes of the member for Hotham (Mr Crean) and the member for Hunter (Mr Fitzgibbon)âtwo men who could have some sway and assist in the political push to get the Redbank project back on the rails. The member for Hotham told this House on 29 May 1997 that `the Redbank project cannot go ahead because the Howard government has abolished the infrastructure bonds which were essential to the funding of that program'.

Recently, on a sortie to the Hunter, the member repeated that John Howard had stood in the way of Redbank. What ridiculous pollie-babble when he knows that my government announced around $30 million in infrastructure tax rebate support for Redbank last September. I quote the member for Hotham on 29 May 1997:
I think the government needs to guarantee that the Redbank power station will go ahead; the people of the Hunter deserve nothing less than that.
Again, on 29 May, the member for Hotham said:

. . . I want to refer specifically to is the Redbank power station because, as the member for Hunter . . . indicated, he and I visited it very recently and this is of major concern to the community of the Hunter.
On 20 March 1997, the member for Hotham said:

The Redbank power project in the Hunter Valleyâa $300 million project which uses coal tailings as fuelâis frozen. I know that the member for Hunter . . . has serious concerns about this particular project being put on ice.
On 29 May 1997, the member for Hotham said, `It is a very significant initiative for the Hunter.'

Later statements by the Director of National Power Australia, Roy Alper, in a letter of appreciation given to me following the announcement, confirm the ridiculous position of the member for Hotham. He said:
We are delighted by the Commonwealth government's decision to assure the project support under a new infrastructure investment program. It means we can proceed to close our financing.
I am absolutely disgusted by the attitude of the Labor Party over this. The member for Hunter said in this House, of his support for the Redbank power station project:
. . . it is an important project in my electorate which would provide jobs.
That was on 29 May. Again on 29 May he said:
. . . contractual arrangements have already been entered into with EnergyAustralia for the provision of electricity.

If this was a private sector organisation which had reneged in this way, Redbank would have had them in the courts for a breach of contract, or in the courts of equity seeking some other form of remedy.
I put to you that that is exactly what has happened. The state government of New South Wales has broken a contract and the Redbank power project people are seeking remedy.

Quite clearly, what we have here is the member for Hunter and the member for Hotham coming into this House, spruiking on, and espousing how much they support employment growth. But they do not have the ability within their own Labor Party structure to convince Bob Carr and his Labor mates of the New South Wales Right that employment in the Hunter is of critical need. What they are prepared to do is to waste hundreds of millions of taxpayers' dollars and sacrifice jobs as well. I know that the taxpayers' dollars would be better spent on providing jobs for the people in the Hunter. The only question I ask is: where do their hearts and souls really lie? Are they with the Redbank power project and its jobs in this big ticket investment, or are they with their soul mates in the New South Wales Right ripping at the heart of Redbank's project?

There is only so much I can do beyond sitting back in amazement at the brouhaha that is soon to be played out in the courtroom. It is obvious that the words of the Labor Party only rebound here in Canberra; they carry no effect in New South Wales. To sum it up, I need only quote the member for Barton (Mr McClelland) on 29 May, when speaking about it. He said:

When we are looking at the consequences of likely massive unemployment in the Newcastle region, the Redbank power project, for instance, would be an excellent example of the employment creating and hence government revenue creating measures which would have followed.

I urge the member for Hunter, the member for Hotham and the Leader of the Opposition to convince their mates in New South Wales that employment growth and jobs in the Hunter, which could be provided through Redbank, are important; and they should get off their tails and do something about it.

talk.start.para: âThe fact is that the Redbank power station would have been under construction by 1 March 1997 if the Howard government had not knocked over the former federal government's infrastructure borrowing scheme. On this issue I have been critical of the state government, but the point is that the price of electricity in New South Wales would not have been an issue if that power station had begun construction on 1 March 1997. That construction did not commenceâ
âMadam Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order.
âThis is outrageous. He knows I have one minute of time and he is going to take a most frivolous point of order. You know that to be the case.

âMadam Deputy Speaker, on the point of order, you reminded me of sub judice. He is arguing a contractual point there about the price of electricity which may or may not have influenced the outcome. (Time expired)

Ordered that the amendments be taken into consideration forthwith.

talk.start.para: âI move:

speech.para: That the amendments be agreed to.

The Stevedoring Levy (Collection) Bill 1998 and the Stevedoring Levy (Imposition) Bill 1998 were passed through the Senate on Friday, 26 June 1998 with a number of minor amendments to the collection bill. I commend the amendments to the House.

When the coalition took office we said we would act to fix the waterfront. We committed ourselves to actively seeking to achieve waterfront reform. We have never wavered from our resolute determination to eliminate overmanning, tackle labour inefficiency, and improve the productivity and reliability of our wharvesâand we have delivered on our promises. With the passage of this legislation, we have taken another major step in reforming workplace relations on the Australian waterfront. The bills will facilitate fundamen tal restructuring by assisting stevedores to meet the costs of redundancy benefits associated with reducing the size of their work forces, improve training, lower the appalling level of workplace injury and introduce new technology. The settlement between Patrick Stevedores, its employees and the MUA will be the first instance of reform and modernisation supported by the legislation.

The bills will enable the Commonwealth to provide funds for at least 738 redundancies. This will be associated with reforms by which Patrick will be able to subcontract services such as maintenance, cleaning and security; to introduce annualised salaries and productivity bonuses, based on targets of 25 crane moves per hour; and to replace double-headers, the order of pick, the nick and all the other rorts and scams with new, flexible rostering and working arrangements. The settlement also provides for genuine freedom of association on the waterfront, where employees will have a choice of whether to join a union or not.

This, of course, is only the beginning. The bills will encourage other stevedores to sign up to the government's seven benchmark objectives so that they will have access to assistance for approved purposes. P&O Ports have already indicated that they will soon be seeking to introduce similar reforms. I anticipate that other employers, including the smaller stevedores, will also want to take advantage of the reform agenda. I have been informed as such by some of them and I certainly encourage them to do so.

I said that we would fix up the waterfront by Christmas, and I am still working to that timetable. The MUA cannot procrastinate. The same is expected not just of P&O but also of Sealand in Adelaide. For Sealand, it is just as important. That company is a monopoly in the Port of Adelaide. It is very important that it reduce overmanning so that its customers in South Australia can see, and reap the benefits from, a more efficient waterfront.

Let me turn briefly to the amendments. I will commence with new clause 19A, `Reports by the Minister'. The Senate committee sought changes to ensure a proper level of scrutiny of the Commonwealth funding of reform and restructuring of the industry. The Senate inserted a new clause 19A, which requires the minister to report to parliament on a range of matters. Reports which must be presented to the parliament will be approximately quarterly during 1998, and annually after that. We support the principle of parliamentary accountability.

Clause 18 is the minister's power to authorise expenditure in connection with stevedoring industry reform. Clause 18 of the collection bill allowed the minister to authorise payments in connection with, or incidental to, reform or restructuring of the industry. The minority report of the Senate committee recommended that the power of the minister to authorise expenditure be clarified. The amendments moved by the opposition were unworkable for a number of reasons.

However, in line with the government's intention that payments under clause 18 only be used to support reform initiatives consistent with the government's objectives, the government proposed its own amendments to clause 18 to specify more precisely the matters to which the minister may authorise payments. As amended, the clause will allow the minister to authorise payments in connection with what are termed `qualifying redundancies'.

The minister may also authorise payments connected with the following reform initiatives: occupational health and safety programs, training programs that aim to improve performance of work, the introduction of new technology and improvement of wharf facilities. These reflect aspects of the seven benchmark objectives. I should also note that, if other reform related activities not included in this list are to be funded, this can only occur if those are prescribed by regulation and the statutory disallowance period has passed.

I emphasise that payments may be for a broad range of reform initiatives and not just redundancies. The legislation is available to benefit all stevedores, including those smaller stevedores who have indicated that they have no present intention to reduce the size of their work force.

As time is getting away from me, I reiterate the government's intention to exempt local cargo from the levy. I announced on 12 June that we would do so. We intended to do so by legislation. However, after further consideration, the exemption will be by way of regulation. I have spoken to the Premier of Tasmania, the Hon. Anthony Rundle MHA. He is satisfied that proceeding by regulation is reasonable in the circumstances, and a regulation has already been drafted to that effect to be brought into effect as soon as possible.

In conclusion, I thank members and senatorsâand you, Madam Deputy Speaker, for your patienceâfor dealing with the legislation quickly and efficiently. There remain fundamental differences between the parties and between the government and the opposition on reform of the waterfront. We also see differences on reform of the shipping industry. We are determined, however, to achieve real and lasting reform in the interests of the national economy and the country generally. This legislation is one part of that program.

talk.start.para: âThe opposition continues to oppose the Stevedoring Levy (Collection) Bill 1998 and the Stevedoring Levy (Imposition) Bill 1998, which have been brought back to the House today by the Minister for Workplace Relations and Small Business (Mr Reith). However, we will not divide on the two amendments that have come back from the Senate because they do slightly ameliorate what we see as bad legislation. We have no wish to return this legislation to its original form, which was even worse.

speech.para: I will comment on the three issues that we find objectionable in the legislation, each one having been referred to by the minister. One was the level of parliamentary scrutiny provided for in the legislation over the operations and dealing with money of MIFCo. That largely has been corrected by one of the amendments that the minister has put forward today. Although it is not quite as strong as the version we put to the Senate, it is nonetheless acceptable as a means of ensuring that the operations of this body and its dealing with money are sufficiently subject to parliamentary scrutiny.

Of the other two issues on which we have very considerable differences with the govern ment, the first is the question of the scope of the activities for which money may be paid out of the funds at the discretion of the minister. In our view, this should have been limited purely to a situation of bona fide redundancies in the entitlements of workers made redundant. The minister did seek to add a number of areas to that. Although rather suspicious of the ministers' motive, given the performance he has put in on this issue so far, we were prepared to accept an extension to issues such as health and safety and technological change disbursements.

However, subclause (c) in the amendment was ultimately adopted by the Senate in spite of our opposition. That empowers any payment with respect to `reform or restructuring of the stevedoring industry', provided that that is made by regulation. That, in our view, is far too broad and opens up the possibility that a variety of dubious payments may be made. For example, if you look at the recent past, the Dubai exercise could have been funded or the legal costs of Chris Corrigan paid for on that basis. Although there is a minor improvement in the sense that any such payments now have to be the subject of regulationsâwhich therefore are disallowableâthat is insufficient protection from the sorts of things that the minister and this government may wish to do in the wake of this legislation.

We do not accept their analysis of the Australian waterfront. As the minister indicated, we have a fundamental disagreement not only as to the current situation on the waterfront but also as to what is the right approach to bring about further improvement and ongoing productivity increases on the waterfront. We think that recent history has shown their motives to be malignant, that their approach to this issue is a devious and mendacious approach and that, therefore, they cannot be trusted to have carte blanche with respect to public moneyâmoney that is paid in taxes on containers and vehicles being transported across Australia's waterfront for these sorts of purposes.

The other issue which the minister mentioned, for which we unsuccessfully sought to have the legislation amended in the Senate, is the question of which stevedores this legisla tion should apply to. The two main stevedores in Australia, P&O and Patrick's, both signed up to the minister's seven supposed benchmarks for reform in the industry. They both supported the legislation, in effect. Therefore, we have no problems with the legislation applying to them and their containers and with their vehicles being the subject of the levy.

We do, however, have a very big problem with the legislation applying to other stevedores without their consentâin particular, stevedores such as Strang in Melbourne and Sealand in Adelaide, who made it very, very plain that they were opposed to what the minister was doing. They did not intend to have redundancies. Contrary to the accusations of the minister, they are not overstaffed at the moment; that is an absolute untruth. They have no intention of using this legislation, and they do not wish to be bullied by the minister into going down the path that Patrick's is going down.

I notice with some amusement that the minister announced on Friday that Labor had caved in to his demands on these issues. We have heard nothing more of that because we did not cave in. We maintained our position all the way through in the Senate on this issue. We continue to maintain our position that this legislation should not apply to stevedoring companies that do not wish to be part of it and that those companies should have an opt out provision. Unfortunately, we were not successful on that in the Senate. As far as we are concerned, this remains bad legislation. But, as I have said, of the two amendments that have been put forward today, one is a good amendment which we accept to improve parliamentary scrutiny and the other marginally improves the scrutiny with respect to what the money can be used for, but nowhere near as much as it should.

talk.start.para: âI think it is appropriate that there be some response to some of the points that have been made. Firstly, in respect of having a uniform levy, this is the same approach that the Labor Party took when they were in government with the WIRA process in 1989. The levy was applied uniformly across the industry, and it is rank hypocrisy for them to say now that the world is different and therefore there should be a different arrangement.

speech.para: The fact is that Sealand have been very close to the MUA, and the MUA want a special deal for their mates. That is not a proposition that this government accepts. It is no surprise that the Labor Party would stand here and advocate the case as directed to them by the MUA. From the government's perspective, a uniform rate is consistent with what Labor did when they were in government. It is obviously the appropriate way to go. As far as Sealand are concerned, they are overmanned in Adelaide. They are a monopoly. They have a hidden deal with the state government in South Australia which is passing costs on to consumers. As far as the federal government is concerned, we expect higher productivity from Sealand, as we do from others. They ought to be taking advantage of this scheme. The fact that they will now be paying the levy will hopefully put some pressure on them to provide a far better service than we have seen so far. It would be in the interests of South Australia if they were to do so.

Secondly, the opposition says that these funds should be entirely limited to redundancies and that they are opposed to the amendments. No-one should forget that, when they were running their reform process, I think $500,000 was paid out to the union as part of a secret sweetheart deal done with the MUA back in 1989. So they do not come to this debate with clean hands. The government does have some wider discretion which this legislation provides us with to pursue our reform agenda, and that is a sensible power for the government to have, as the reform process is an evolutionary one.

Lastly, my opposite number says that the government's motives are malignant. This, I must say, brings a smile to my face. As I was reading the press reports in 1994 of the relationship between the MUA and the federal Labor government, it was said by one independent commentator that the MUA had demonised Laurie Brereton and put him in the pantheon of stars along with Stanley Mel bourne Bruce and somebody else that the MUA did not like at the time. The reality is that the MUA finds malignant the motives of anybody who is attempting to reform the waterfront, whether it is a coalition government as it is today or a Labor government as it was back in 1994.

Why is it that governments of both political persuasions have looked to reform the Australian waterfront? The reason is that productivity levels have been very poor, and that has imposed a very great cost on the Australian community. Governments of both political persuasions have had a national responsibility to do what they can to fix up the waterfront. What we now know from reading the Australian this morning is that the then Labor government looked at all the range of options which we as a government have looked at. It was a Labor government that received legal advice on cancelling the MUA's awards and agreements. What incredible hypocrisy for the Labor Party to accuse us of malignant motives when they had a subcommittee of a federal Labor government that looked at getting rid of the MUA's awards and agreements.

They also looked at the deregistration of the MUA. Why would they look at the deregistration of the MUA? Because they shelled out a huge amount of taxpayers' money to reform the waterfront, got nothing for it and then found themselves subject to an industrial campaign of blackmail by the MUA years after they were supposed to fix up the waterfront. What else did they seek legal advice on? They sought legal advice on the dismissal of the employees. What was omitted from the documents, I am reliably informed, the one thing they did not look at, was a proper redundancy program for the people who might have been dismissed as a result of such action.

The hypocrisy of the Labor Party revealed in the Australian this morning reinforces in the end that this has been a government determined to fix up the waterfront. This is not a government that caves in, as Labor always does, to the unions. That is why ultimately there will be no divisions here, as there were no divisions in the Senateâbecause the Labor Party knows that it is about time the waterfront was fixed up, and this legislation is part of it. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âThere are many points in the contribution of the Minister for Workplace Relations and Small Business (Mr Reith) that I would take issue with, but given the time that is available to me I will address only two. The first is the purported analogy between the current stevedoring levy legislation that he is seeking to impose and the levy that was imposed on the stevedoring industry by the Labor government in 1989. There is one fundamental difference between the two situations which makes the analogy totally fallacious, and that is that in 1989 you had pooled employment. There were no employees of the individual stevedoring companies; you had pooled employment. If you were going to have a stevedoring industry levy to fund redundancies, by definition it had to be on everybody because there were no separate employees in individual enterprises.

speech.para: Therefore, the analogy is totally redundant. It is totally inappropriate, because in order to have a levy and a pool of money to fund redundancies clearly that had to be on everybody because you could not distinguish between individual employees and say, `This person is an employee of P&O; this person is an employee of Sealand,' which you can now do. To the best of my recollection, there were no stevedoring employers at the time seriously kicking up a major fuss about the levy proposal, as there are now. There was no equivalence then, to the best of my recollection, to Sealand and Strang now saying, `We don't want to be part of this. We don't want to make any of our workers redundant. We don't believe that we are overstaffed. We believe that we are operating in a reasonable way.' So it is a totally false analogy.

The second point I would like to take issue with is this incredible beat-up: this suggestion that, because somebody in the departmental bureaucracy a few years ago put a paper together to the minister of the timeâwhoever it wasâalong with all the various things that go backwards and forwards, saying, `You have these options,' that in some way means there was some sort of culpability on the part of the minister or the government at the time.
Mr Reith interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âWhat we have here is somebody who has actively conspired over 18 months with a major stevedoring employer to engage in dodgy corporate restructuring, to sack en masse their entire work force, and has got up and lied to the Australian public about it and said, `No, I didn't know anything about this.'
âOrder! The honourable member should withdraw that comment.
âI withdraw the word `lied'.
âAnd apologise.
âOh, you must be joking!
âWhen he withdraws he has apologised.

âYou must be joking. On 8 May, at a doorstop, the minister said, `I do not know anything about what Chris Corrigan's plans were.' If you look at a minute which was submitted to the cabinet on 7 July 1997, almost a year previously, you will see that under his own name is a statement of detail of the specific strategy that Chris Corrigan and Patrick were then to pursue. He did not know anything about the strategy, but he has actually put a submission to cabinet telling everybody about it.

speech.para: Then we subsequently discover that there is a minute of discussions that have been held on 14 April between his own departmental officials and Patrick that goes into great detail, including on the corporate restructuring, about what is going to be done, and there is a notation on that minute saying that he was advised of this on 19 April 1997. So I will withdraw the specific word, Mr Deputy Speaker, but if the cap fits wear it. And that is precisely what we are talking about here.

You have got a situation where this man has done those things and then he says that, because there was a former Labor government that some bureaucrat sent advice to and said, `You could do these things,' that somehow means that Laurie Brereton, the then Minister for Transport in that government, is in some way culpable for that thing when he has got no evidence whatsoever that there were any decisions made of any nature along the lines that he has indicated. Of course, no action was taken by the former government along the lines that he has indicatedânone at all.

I suspect that that piece of advice was probably consigned to the round filing cabinet, as should have been the advice that this minister received from his department about the corporate restructuringâabout the dogs and the balaclavas and the mass sackings. But he did not do that. He actually went ahead and did the things. That is the fundamental difference.

Our former government got a bit of advice about this and it did not act on it. It did not do anything. It got a bit of departmental advice, but this minister got that advice and he orchestrated it and he did it. He orchestrated the mass sackings. He went in there and said, `Don't worry, forget about your jobs, you're gone,' and that is the fundamental difference. That analogy is the biggest beat-up of all time and I think that the former ministers in the Labor government can sleep easily tonight about that claim because I do not think they have anything to worry about.

talk.start.para: âI realise that in this parliament we are not allowed to use that word which you, Mr Deputy Speaker, just required to be withdrawn, but can I say with regard to this matter that this minister has said one thing, consciously knowing the facts to be otherwise. Consistently, he has made public statements contrary to what he knows the facts to be.

speech.para: He made an interjection about hypocrisy earlier. Nobody cared about it being withdrawn because nobody would care about what he says. But I have to say that is one area in which I acknowledge the minister's undoubted expertise. Hypocrisy is the one thing in this discussion about which I am prepared to say that he is an expert beyond all others and deserves the proper recognition of this House and I am prepared to acknowledge that.

talk.start.para: âIs this really relevant, Mr Deputy Speaker?
âIt has been a fairly wide-ranging debate.
âThey are the only two things which I think this minister has done well with regard to the matters covered by this legislation.

speech.para: There are two other things that I wish to refer to. They have been covered already, but I want to speak to them more specifically. One is that the proposal that people who do not wish to draw on the fund should be required to contribute to it is simply another stage in a saga whereby this minister has set out consciously to assist Patrick and use the taxpayers' resources, and now the competitors' resources.
Mr Reith interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âOh, you have used taxpayers' resources in other regards, but in this matter you are using the competitors' resources to assist Patrick in return for their engaging in a series of actions designed to serve the political cause of this government. The taxpayer is underwriting this proposition, but it is worse that it is the competitors of Patrick that are being required to fund their operation.

speech.para: People should not have the right to draw on a fund to which they do not contribute. That is a perfectly reasonable proposition. Nor should they have the right to draw on a fund to which their competitors are compulsorily required to contribute, but on which those competitors do not wish to draw. This is a clear indication that, as part of the deal with Patrick, the government had to commit to requiring the competitors to contribute, whether they wished to draw on the funds or not. It is an extraordinary and unreasonable proposition. The second extraordinary and unreasonable proposition is that because somebody sends a file across to you with a memo, about which you disagree and which you rejectâ

talk.start.para: âOh yeah!

âThe evidence is pretty clear. What action was taken on the basis on it? Zero. It was rejected. Let us say, it is extraordinary that you are culpable for the actions of a person sending you a piece of paper and then you reject it. I have to say that I rejected quite a few recommendations from my department that came across in three yearsânone of them with as much gusto as I might have rejected this particular one. But I was prepared to disagree with my department on a number of occasions, and that is not a reflection on them. It is their responsibility to send across a range of options. The fact that a minister rejects them and finds them unacceptableâthey send them up to the next one and the mug accepts them.
âWho asked for them?

âYou do not always have to ask for things to get them. You know that. But you have to be a mug to fall for them, and we are delighted that you were. The best thing for us is this: we do not think that the next time you are surveyed you will even get three per cent. That is the thing that encourages us most about this whole debate.

speech.para: Question resolved in the affirmative.

talk.start.para: âI move:

speech.para: That the requested amendments be agreed to.

I can advise at the outset that the government accepts the amendments requested by the Senate. The bill contains a number of measures announced by the government in last year's budget, including the extension of carer payment to carers of profoundly disabled children and significant reforms to the way social security means tested retired people's income streams.

Members may be aware that this bill was before the Senate at the end of May, but the Senate made amendments that were at that time unacceptable to the government. The government was disappointed at that time that parties in the Senate had put at risk all of the beneficial measures in the bill that would have helped carers of older Australians as well as the disabled. However, we have since been heartened by the more constructive attitude taken by these same parties in coming to a compromise that enhances the bill in a way which is affordable. I would like to thank the honourable member for Jagajaga (Ms Macklin) for her cooperation in achieving this outcome.

I will outline the requests as I understand them: (1) to (6) relate to the mobility allowance. Mobility allowance is a payment designed to assist disabled people undertaking training. Centrelink was paying mobility allowance in cases where people were travelling to life skills training but, unfortunately, that was not technically permissible under the act. The government recognises such training is valuable and these requests will make it possible.

Requests (2) to (5)relate to the carers of profoundly disabled children measure. The government has been willing to listen to concerns raised by care and disabled groups, and in the Senate, about the targeting of the measure. These requests expand the availability of the carer payment to more carers, in particular to cases where there are two or more severely disabled children being cared for. Carers are one of the most under-recognised groups in our community and this measure, as well as other aspects of the government's carer package, goes some way to addressing their very special needs. Obviously, this is an important measure. It is good to have the amendments before us which can be accepted and therefore have the bill and the budget measures in place. I therefore commend the requests to the House.

talk.start.para: âWe are pleased that the government has supported the amendments that were moved in the Senate, even though there was quite a bit of disagreement over some of the issues. People would be aware that the government put a lot of people with disabilities through a lot of misery at the end of last year by taking their mobility allowances away from them, and we are very pleased that that issue has been cleaned up and people can know that they will get their mobility allowances to ensure that they get to their activities without being any further out of pocket.

speech.para: As far as the carer issues go, we were very concernedâand I made some very critical remarks on this part of the bill when I was making my speech on the second reading in the Houseâthat very few carers and their profoundly disabled children would benefit from this important reform. To a degree the problem remains, and the child has to be extremely disabled. There are a number of children who, from our point of view, are extremely or profoundly disabled and who still will not qualify for this payment. Nevertheless, we are pleased that the government has accepted one amendment that we made to at least benefit some children who by any definition would be considered to be profoundly disabled.

Under our amendment it is no longer necessary that a child have both urinary and faecal incontinence day and night. Under our amendment it is sufficient for the child to have faecal incontinence day and night. This amendment will be welcomed by those parents who are caring for children in this situation. The government also moved an amendment under which the condition of profound disability is satisfied if the child is under three, and we welcome that amendment as well.

The Democrats moved an amendment, which I am pleased to see the government has accepted, that provides for payment where a person is caring for two or more disabled children, each of whom does not satisfy the criteria by themselves but where the level of care required in respect of the disabled children taken together is equivalent to that required by a profoundly disabled child. We were very pleased to support that amendment by the Democrats.

There was one other important thing which I would just like to put on the record. The Minister for Social Security (Senator Newman) made an undertaking that the effect of the provisions would be subject to a review after 12 months. She said in a letter to meâand she also said this in the Senateâthat the government would undertake a review of the carer payment measure after 12 months, focusing in particular on whether any profoundly disabled children are not benefiting from the measure, and that the review would be tabled in the Senate. She did repeat that undertaking before the Senate for the record. Given our earlier concerns that very few children would benefit from this important reform, I am very pleased that the government has agreed to undertake such a review.

The other issue I want to touch on is seasonal workers. I foreshadowed in my earlier remarks in the House the need to take into account the fact that some seasonal workers do stints of work and live on their savings in the intervening periods. I am pleased to say that the government moved amendments to address this point. The government has agreed to our amendments under which work-related expenses can be deducted from a person's seasonal work earnings where the worker shows that they are allowable tax deductions.

So there have been some improvements made to this bill. There will also be some protection by administrative review of those people who bought income stream products prior to 1992. I certainly hope that those people will be protected by that process of administrative review.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

talk.start.para: âOn behalf of the Minister for Finance and Administration (Mr Fahey), I move:

speech.para: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, the following proposed work be referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works for consideration and report: CSIRO National Centre for Petroleum and Mineral Resources Research, Bentley, WA.

The National Centre for Petroleum and Mineral Resources Research is being established by the Western Australian government and CSIRO to substantially increase Western Australia's technological capability and its capacity to support the sustained development of its resource industries. Located at Technology Park in Bentley, the national centre will provide a focal point for research excellence and collaboration between CSIRO, cooperative research centres, university researchers, government agencies, resource companies and associated technology suppliers and providers.

The national centre will provide a unique opportunity to bring together world-class scientific and engineering research groups to work closely with the petroleum and minerals industries. Collaborative research will embrace a wide range of activities aimed not only at providing solutions to current industry issues but also at providing the research leadership necessary to address the key research needs and research issues of these industries now and in the decades ahead.

The concentration of capability and expertise at the national centre will also provide a major incentive for leading edge companies and organisations to locate their operations in Western Australia, further enhancing the prospects for research collaboration and technology transfer and the delivery of innovative research solutions, services and products to the petroleum and minerals industries. The centre represents a marriage of the leading edge research in minerals and petroleum exploration and production with the industry sector.

The proposed development will include laboratories and research facilities, process bays, support and stores areas, staff amenities, public facilities, associated site works, roadworks, car parking, engineering and communication services and landscaping.
The estimated outturn cost is $31.8 million. It is anticipated that construction will commence early in mid-1999 and be completed by late 2000. I commend the motion to the House.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

talk.start.para: âOn behalf of the Minister for Finance and Administration (Mr Fahey), I move:

speech.para: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, the following proposed work be referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works for consideration and report: Lavarack Barracks Redevelopment Stage 2, Townsville.

The Department of Defence proposes to redevelop Lavarack Barracks. The works now proposed are needed to overcome acute accommodation inadequacies, to improve efficiency and operational effectiveness, and to provide a sound infrastructure framework on which further development of the barracks can proceed.

The works are in nine main components consisting of accommodation and messing, operational, logistic support and infrastructure development facilities. The main components comprise new living-in accommodation for 1,112 officers, senior non-commissioned officers and other ranks, associated mess complexes and a central food preparation facility.

The estimated out-turn cost of the proposal is $139.3 million. Subject to parliamentary approval, the works would be committed in September 1998âthat is, this yearâwith the objective of having them completed by December 2001. I commend the motion to the House.

talk.start.para: âThis project is in my electorate of Herbert, where we have Australia's largest defence base. It is located at Lavarack Barracks in the city of Townsville. This is stage two of the redevelopment of Lavarack, and a very welcome stage indeed. The $139 million being proposed tonight will be used to repair and refurbish the living-in accommodation that exists at the barracks. That living-in accommodation is 30 years old. It is run-down. In typical rooms you almost cannot swing a cat. There is an absence of flyscreening and airconditioning. There are centralised ablutions. It is just not appropriate for a modern army to have facilities like this.

speech.para: This Public Works Committee hearing will investigate and hopefully approve this expenditure to upgrade that living-in accommodation that was promised to the army by Minister Bishop when she visited there some 12 months ago. This money will also do things like improve the centralised messing, the logistics, the operational areas and so on. It is a very worthwhile project. I would also like to inform the House that following this stage a further stage will come to the parliament for approval. Stage three is estimated to cost about $159 million and that will see the entire upgrade of Australia's largest army base.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

talk.start.para: âAs a member of the Joint Standing Committee on Migration, I rise to support the report of the committee on criminal deportation and to say a few words about this important report and the approach which the report has taken. I want to say from the beginning that, given there were controversial issues, the fact that this report is signed by all members of the committee indicates the importance of having a committee such as this committee, the Joint Standing Committee on Migration.

speech.para: Given that there is so much misrepresentation on migration issues, especially in the politics of the moment, I think that it is very important for a committee like this to continue to operate and to try to achieve as much bipartisan support as possible so that we have an agreement within this society on the sensitive issues of immigration. In that regard, I must say that I was concerned about a recent parliamentary report which suggested that, in the next parliament, this particular parliamentary committee might be abolished. I think that this would be a very big mistake not only for the parliament but also for our society. Our society is very interested in issues concerning migration and in the factual information put forward to this committee representing the views of others in the society.

It is very important that we do not support the proposal to abolish the migration committee in the next parliament. It is important that we support the work of this committee which, as I said before, can help to build consensus in our society about these sensitive migration issues. The work of this committee can also educate the public as to what is actually happening in migration as distinct from all the nonsense which people such as the member for Oxley (Ms Hanson) wish to peddle about the immigration program and what is happening with it.

Those people who think that the situation with the immigration program is such that the government and the opposition are taking a soft approach to the tough issues of immigration ought to read this report, because this is very tough report on the deportation of non-citizen criminals. Basically, this report proposes that the current powers of the minister and the government be extendedâperhaps not as much as some members of the committee wanted. But, as I said before, the negotiation and reaching of consensus within the committee mean that, on the one hand, the committee is recommending to the government a toughening up of the provisions but, on the other hand, the committee is saying that we still have to be sure that people are treated with fairness.

There are a number of important aspects to this recommendation, but one of the most important is the recommendation that the minister be given the power to set aside decisions of the AAT on deportation matters if the minister regards the outcome as being in the national interest. This is an important power. It will increase the powers of the minister, but it is important in order to deal with phenomena such as those which have occurred recently in relation to deportation. People were able, for technical reasons, to overcome the problem of deportation by using the AAT when it was quite clear that, on the basis of justice and fairness, these people should have been deported.

I think that, in those cases, the minister will be given this power, and I would support the minister gaining that power. However, there are two requirements of the minister if he exercises this power which are consistent with our Westminster system approach. Firstly, he must table an outline of the reasons for the exercise of this power in parliament within 15 days. Secondly, the committee will formally review the way in which the minister has exercised this power after a three-year period of the exercise of the power.

These recommendations are very reasonable recommendations in the circumstances. They do toughen up the provisions for deportation. Of course, we are talking about non-citizensâpeople who came to Australia and did not become citizens either because they did not fit within the two-year period or because they chose not to become citizens after the two-year period. We are not talking about Australian citizens; we are talking about non-citizens who break the law.

In relation to that, there exists in the current provisions a 10-year rule which allows people after 10 years, if they are non-citizens, to be treated as if they were citizens. Effectively they cannot be deported. The committee is now recommending in regard to what we call `very serious offences', which can be specified in regulations and which include things like murder, serious sexual assaults, drug dealing and armed robbery, that a person who commits one such offence will be liable for deportation, even if it is after the 10-year period. That is a toughening up, but it is a totally justified toughening up. If somebody resides in our society for whatever period of time and commits these very serious offences they should be liable to deportation.

A second matter has to do with offences attracting jail terms of at least 12 months. These offences are less than the very serious offences. If a person commits one such offence, they are given a warning and are told: `If this is repeated, you will be subject to deportation.' The committee is recommending that, on the basis of a second such offence, that person would be liable to deportation. That is a reasonably fair sort of arrangement to be putting in place in relation to this situation.

Not only will the minister have the power to overturn AAT recommendations, but in recommendation 17 the minister will also be given the powerâif these recommendations are adoptedâto grant in the public interest or on compassionate or humanitarian grounds a visa to a previously deported person. This means that the minister, in effect, can consider these cases and decide that, on balance, for humanitarian considerations he may not exercise his power.

This is important in the case of children or in the case of family considerations, such as a situation relating to the breadwinner in the family. If they have had two repeat offences, strictly speaking they should be subject to deportation. But if there are children involved or if a family situation is involved or if the minister considers there are sufficient humanitarian considerations, the minister can take that into account. However, the ministerâand indeed those reviewing the matterâmust take into account victim impact statements. This means that if people have committed these crimes against Australians, especially if they are non-citizens, then there should be a prima facie case in general for deportation under the circumstances I have explained but it should also be the case that where their victims wish to put in victim impact statements they should be allowed to do so, so that a balanced and just look at the matter can be taken.

In overall terms this is a balanced approach to this very complicated issue. I commend the committee for the work done on this report and the chairperson, the honourable Chris Gallus. As I said at the beginning, this is a very fine example of the way parliamentary committees can work to achieve positive outcomes. I am sure the government will adopt the general balanced approach which is recommended in this report Deportation of non-citizen criminals.

talk.start.para: âWhen the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs (Mr Ruddock) sought this inquiry back in February of 1997 he said in his media release that Australia's overseas born population generally has a lower propensity to criminal activity. When we have a debate of this kind it is worth making that point right up front, right at the outset, because I know there are a few urban myths to the contrary. It is worth pointing out that the minister himself, in seeking an inquiry into criminal deportation policies, did make clear the lower propensity to criminal activity on the part of Australia's overseas born population.

speech.para: The Joint Standing Committee on Migration has completed an 18-month report and inquiry into criminal deportation. Its call for submis sions resulted in some 58 submissions. It took more than 300 transcript pages of oral evidence. So it is a comprehensive report on the deportation of non-citizens. Its objective is the protection to the Australian community provided by deporting non-citizens who are convicted of serious offences.

Labor, in supporting this report and in commenting on it, is concerned to ensure that criminals or people who are members of gangs do not come to Australia and that, if they do commit offences in Australia, they are deported. We do not want to see people here who are going to intimidate Australian residents. I also express the view that those who indulge in racial vilification and in promoting and fostering racial hatred should not be welcome in this country, either. This was also our position in the Migration Legislation Amendment (Strengthening Provisions Relating to Character and Conduct) Bill, which was introduced to the House by the government going back a bit.

The committee that prepared this report found that we need to maintain some safeguard against authorities acting on the basis of information provided in malice rather than information which is properly founded. The deportation policy outlined in the report enforces stricter determination criteria and proposes that what is known as the 10-year rule should be amended in relation to very serious offenders and also in relation to repeat offences. The inquiry reflects evidence that the Australian community wants to see a fair and effective scheme protecting our nation from criminal non-citizens.

Against that background the committee made recommendations based on the evidence that it received to modify aspects of the structure of the present scheme. This included amendments to the review arrangements to reflect the central role of the minister as policy maker. The scheme is to protect the Australian community against the risk of further criminal acts by non-citizens while ensuring that international legal conventions and the individual rights of non-citizens are also considered in the process. They recommended changes to the statutory limit on non-citizens' liability to deportation.

para.inline: Sitting suspended from 6.30 p.m. to 8.00 p.m.

talk.start.para: âAs I was saying prior to the break, the recommendations involve a number of changes including: proposals which would ensure that serious crimes after 10 years residency can still be considered under the deportation arrangements; changes concerning the information exchange between state and territory justice and prison agencies to ensure that each non-citizen prisoner is considered in a fair manner; and the ministerial deportation policy statement which would specify all relevant community views and the weight to be given to those views.

speech.para: I turn now to the recommendations of the committee in the conclusions section of the report. I will set them out for the benefit of the House. The committee proposed that the Migration Act be amended to:
(a) provide the Minister with a power to set aside an AAT decision on deportation matters if the Minister regards this outcome as being in the national interest;
(b) require the Minister, when exercising the power, to table an outline of the reasons before each House of Parliament within 15 sitting days.

It is clear on the face of it that that proposal would amount to an increase in the powers of the minister in relation to deportation matters. It is also suggested that the minister ought to be subject to:
. . . a formal review by the appropriate committee of the parliament three years after the tabling of this report.

As I mentioned before, the committee proposes some changes to what is known as the 10-year rule. The current legislation limits non-citizen liability to criminal deportation to a maximum of 10 years. As the committee points out in its report:
Should a non-citizen commit even the most heinous of crimes after that time, the law does not allow for deportation.
The committee suggests that the 10-year limit ought to be amended to give greater weight to the interests of the wider community. It recommends:

The ten year rule ought to continue to be applicable to those who came to Australia under the age of 18; and the Ministerial Policy Statement be amended to take account of any particular hardship or potential injustice which might arise in relation to those who came to Australia as children.
It proposes that the 10-year rule be abolished in relation to conviction for very serious offences.
Those offences would be specified in the Regulations and would include murder, serious sexual assaults, drug dealing, armed robbery and . . . other very serious offences . . .
The ministerial policy statement would also create:

. . . an expectation that persons who were previously convicted of an offence and issued with a warning, and who were convicted of another offence which indicates a pattern of continued criminal behaviour, should prima facie be deported.
The committee has also proposed that the Migration Act be:

. . . amended to render non-citizens convicted of a second offence resulting in a custodial sentence of at least 12 months liable to deportation irrespective of when the offences occurred. A non-citizen convicted on a second or subsequent offence (even if the first offence occurred after the ten year period) should become liable to deportation.

The committee also made some recommendations concerning arrangements between state and territory governments. The committee proposed that the Commonwealth seek to negotiate standard procedures with each state and territory government in order to:
(a) identify each non-citizen held in prison as a potential deportee subject to the criminal deportation process; and
(b) verify any citizenship information generated by prisoners with cross-checking of available records.
The committee proposes that the department formalise its relations with each state and territory government using a memorandum of understanding in order to:
(a) overcome deficiencies in current practices;
(b) ensure each party is aware of their agreed obligations; and
(c) clarify the exchange of information under the Migration Act 1958 .
I also note that there are some recommendations concerning the weight of the parties' views concerning deportation matters. The committee recommends that:
. . . the current Ministerial Policy Statement acknowledge the interests of any children involved as one of the primary considerations in the deportation process.
and that:

. . . the Ministerial Policy Statement be amended to ensure that the views of family members are considered in the deportation process, and that the weight to be given to those views follows the proposal contained in the draft Ministerial Policy Statement.

It also recommends that the minister revise the ministerial policy statement to enable victims' views to be recorded in the form of victim impact statements. So there are a number of recommendations made in this area as well.

In relation to the issue of children, it does call up some quite difficult considerations. I did have constituents come to my office pleading the case of a chap who had been subject to quite serious convictions involving heroin trafficking, who had served a substantial period in gaol and who was to be deported. They sought my assistance in relation to this matter. I said to them, `My office prides itself on the extent to which it gives support to constituents, but if I were the minister responsible I would be deporting this person too.' In relation to the issue concerning children, it did strike me that the person concerned would struggle to be a real father when he had been in prison for the past eight years for these heroin trafficking offences and that, indeed, there was a case to be made for the children of other parents in other families who became the victims of heroin trafficking. So there are some difficult issues at stake here.

There have been some calls for this idea of deportation to be extended beyond non-citizens and to migrants generally. I do not support that call in any shape or form. One of the things that I feel very proud of being able to say at citizenship ceremonies is that everyone who becomes an Australian citizen enjoys the same rights as those of us who were born here; that in Australian citizenship there is real equality between people and that all Australian citizens are considered equal. I would certainly argue very strongly against any move away from that position or any suggestion that citizens could be deported, which I understand is now being made in certain quarters. We need to stand for the proposition that citizens are equal. People should be encouraged to become Australian citizens with all the rights and responsibilities that entails. That should be something that people should aspire to and should regard as a very good thing.

It is clear from the report that the committee has done quite valuable work. The member for Calwell (Dr Theophanous) noted that a recommendation has come forward from the Procedure Committee suggesting that the Joint Standing Committee on Migration be abolished. I, in fact, put in a minority report in relation to that because I think that some of the joint standing committees which were proposed for abolition do indeed do valuable work. The report that we are considering here, concerning the deportation of non-citizen criminals, is in that category.
