It is a bipartisan report that makes a number of quite significant recommendations; they are supported on both sides of the House so, hopefully, it will be a useful report which the government can draw on.

talk.start.para: âI want to make a few remarks, on behalf of the Christian Democratic Party, in relation to the report of the Joint Standing Committee on Migration on criminal deportation and generally on the subject of immigration. I congratulate the committee for the work it has done on this report. I enjoyed reading it. In fact, it is the sort of report that ought to be made widely available for citizens to understand the complexities of some of these sorts of issues.

speech.para: There is in the community, as the member for Wills (Mr Kelvin Thomson) quite rightly said, often an attitude that people who have migrated here from other countries and have broken the law after they have become Australian citizens should be deported or sent back to their country of origin. I was pleased to hear the member for Wills say, and I agree entirely with this, that that is a completely unrealistic propositionâbesides the fact that it has practical connotations that would be almost impossible to overcome, in as much as once someone has become an Australian citizen, they do not, of course, have an alternative country of citizenship.

I was also pleased to hear the member for Wills state so clearly what I also believe and that is the equality of all Australian citizens before the law. He alluded to, and I need to underline, the irony of that because the quarters from which some of these suggestions about deporting immigrants to their countries of origin come are all emphasising the need for the treating of Australians equally. Yet, when it comes to something like this there is a suggestionâin the usual glib, simplistic sort of way that we seem to see policies enunciated by some of these peopleâthat, because somebody came from some country at some point of time years ago and has since become an Australian citizen, somehow that Australian citizenship can be stripped from them.

I know of no circumstances in which that can happen. I do not propose to disturb the Attorney-General (Mr Williams), who is at the table, although I am sure he would be the most capable person in this place to answer that question. I am sure, from my limited understanding of the law, that Australian citizenship cannot be stripped from anybody once it has been given to them. I imagine that is the case, and I certainly want to support what the member for Wills has said and, indeed, what the member for Calwell (Dr Theophanous) said. I heard his contribution to this particular debate earlier on. I congratulate the Joint Standing Committee on Migration for its report entitled Deportation of non-citizen criminals.

The Christian Democratic Party certainly believes very strongly in the need for a balanced migrant intake into Australia. We believe that those coming to Australia should understand the commitment they are making with respect to our nation's democratic institutions, traditions and values. We also support increased emphasis on the importance of English language skills for migrants, but we do not go to the extreme of suggesting that everybody who comes here should be able to pass some sort of English test. I was very pleased to see the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs (Mr Ruddock) point out the ridiculous nature of such a proposition and how such a proposition would actually seriously damage the benefits that come to Australia from a number of the different immigrant categories, where people bring all sorts of skills to Australia and at the time that they bring those skills not necessarily having a complete understanding of English. Of course, there are other ramifications of such a suggestion for some of the other migrant programs.

We believeâand I need to say hereâthat immigration is important to Australia. It is obvious that our migrants have served this country enormously well over the years. But it is disturbing when you look at the way public opinion has moved. It was only 20 or 30 years ago that surveys showed that people actually believed that the migrant intake into Australia was too low. Now that, of course, is completely reversed and people believe that it is too high.

In looking for the reasons for that, unfortunately I think we have to look in part to the way that immigration was handled for a number of years in this country, where people lost confidence in our immigration program and it fell into disrepute. Now there is a challenge largely to all of us but certainly on the government to inform people about the benefits of immigration and to expose the flawed argument that somehow, when somebody arrives here, they take somebody else's job. In fact, conventional wisdomâand I certainly agree with itâsays that immigrants come here and actually create jobs rather than take them.

I also want to express the concern that having debates about immigration without talking about population policy also tends to mean that we contribute to the adhocery of these debates about immigration numbers. As a nation, we really need, firstly, to decide what sort of population levels we should be aiming for in time and then to make some more intelligent decisions about how many people ought to come here. The Christian Democratic Party believes that Australia does need a continuing, balanced immigration program. We believe strongly that the immigrants who come here can and will contribute to Australia, as those who have come here in the past have done. We certainly do not believe in any sort of racial discrimination in the way that our immigration program is put together.

In that broad context, this report gives us an opportunity to highlight some of the misconceptions that exist in the community about immigration. There is, unfortunately, a belief that immigrants come here and in disproportionate numbers commit horrific crimes. Of course, when it does happen from time to time, and we are all aware of some of the problems regarding the drug trade, it is very fertile ground for those who want to spread the myth even further that somehow all the people who come here from somewhere else, particularly when they come here from Asia, are undesirable. Quite the reverse is true, and I strongly believe that we should welcome people of all races and cultures here. I think that is very desirable.

In this report we get some interesting ideas about how this particular difficult problem is handled. I am pleased that the minister for immigration has seen fit to refer this to the committee. As has already been said in this debate, the committee has done a very good job of dealing with some complex issues. The fact that they are complex issues underlines the fact that people often have very simplistic views of some of these complex areas. I will quote briefly from the foreword to the report, which is written by the member for Hindmarsh (Mrs Gallus). It says:

Australia's criminal deportation scheme was designed to protect the community from criminal non-citizens while ensuring that Australia fulfils its international and humanitarian obligations towards these non-citizens and their families.

That paragraph is very instructive because it tells us that we have a responsibility towards these people. While they are here as non-citizens, nevertheless they are here legally. That distinction needs to be made. Even if they commit various crimes, they do have rights, and we should recognise those rights and allow them to exercise those rights because in doing so we are fulfilling our international and humanitarian obligations.

Some of the people who want to talk about throwing these people out as soon as they do something wrong also have a fairly jaundiced view of how we enter into international obligations. That debate, almost in parallel with the debate that is going on in the community about immigration, is easily taken out of context and misrepresented. The fact is that we do enter into treaties of various sorts. We have international obligations. It may be that there is a perception that in the past a lot of these obligations have been entered into in some respects lightly or perhaps in some secret fashion. But, to its credit, the present government has changed all that and there is now a very open and transparent process in place whereby all of these treaties are referred to a joint standing committee, so there is a process of parliamentary scrutiny in place. I believe the government has achieved an enormous amount by doing that. Hopefully, in time that particular process will lead to there being a heightened degree of public confidence in the fact that treaties are not entered into lightly and that they are given due parliamentary consideration before they are signed.

The other point that the foreword makes is that we also have humanitarian obligations towards these non-citizens and their families. That is another key issue in the whole report. It addresses the processes by which these people may be deported, and it raises a number of issues which are obviously pertinent on how the families of these people are affected. Very often there are children involved. It may be all right for us to loosely throw some rhetoric around about getting rid of these troublemakers, but the fact is that in a lot of circumstances, whilst they are non-citizens, they may have children who are Australian citizens who would in some circumstances be separated from a father or mother. These things are not simple by any means, but I think this report goes a great way towards clarifying many of the issues of concern, and it does underline that we do have humanitarian obligations towards these non-citizens.

For the purpose of clarifying things, I say that there is also confusion in the community about people who are here in effect illegally, having overstayed their visas. They are subject to removal. The law provides for that. It is applied in a mandatory sense. If someone is found to be here illegallyâthey have been found to have overstayed their visas or they have not complied with the approval they have been given to come hereâthey are removed. That differs from the situation we are dealing with in this report where we are talking about deportation. That deals specifically with non-citizens who are here legally. They have entered Australia, they have a current visa and some degree of temporary or permanent residency, but while they have that status they commit a crime of the sort that would lead to their deportation. The word is not removal in that case but deportation. I think people need to understand that we are dealing with two distinct groups of people here.

I believe, looking at it objectively, that the government, and the minister in particular, have done a very good job and are very even-handed and fair in dealing with some of these complex matters. The minister called for this report because he had some concerns about some aspects of the current law in respect of the deportation of non-citizen criminals, and this will hopefully lead to some changes in the law that will actually clarify some of the issues that are in doubt.
One of the important recommendations I noted as I read the report is the recommendation to:
. . . provide the Minister with a power to set aside an AAT decision on deportation matters if the Minister regards this outcome as being in the national interest . . .
The second part of that recommendation is to:
. . . require the Minister, when exercising the power, to table an outline of the reasons before each House of Parliament within 15 sitting days.

That recommendation addresses the concern that the minister had expressed about the current system. The committee examined the appeal mechanisms which had been criticised by the minister and others, and it concluded that the present review arrangements did not give appropriate weight to the role of the minister intended by the parliament. That is a very important point, and I am pleased to see that this recommendation brings that into focus and restores the power to the minister to exercise his power in respect of these matters, ultimately by being able to make a decision to set aside an AAT decision. I will not go on any longer. I just appreciate the opportunity to make a few remarks and to add my support and commendation to the committee for an excellent report.
Debate (on motion by Ms Ellis) adjourned.

talk.start.para: âAt the outset I must say how much I appreciated the time, effort and sincerity of those individuals and organisations who contributed so much to this inquiry into competitive tendering of welfare service delivery. The Standing Committee on Family and Community Affairs travelled to most capital cities and some regional centres to ensure a base of information that was as broad and informed as possible.

speech.para: When you are asked to conduct an inquiry into the area of welfare service delivery, some emotion must come into it. After all, you are dealing with potential decisions that will affect a great number of individuals and families, a great many of whom are not as well equipped as others to defend their situation. The situation facing clients of welfare services must be considered to be as important asâor, in some cases, more important thanâmerely considering the economic arguments for competitive tendering.

Before considering whether or not it is a good idea to go down the competitive tendering path of welfare services, it is worth while to look at who, in the main, currently delivers these services and to whom. Non-government social welfare organisations operate very broadly, providing a wide range of services to the community. These include aged care, disability services, community, individual and family services, as well as child-care and employment programs. There are some 11,000 community based and church affiliated organisations, along with a number of private for-profit companies and state, territory and Commonwealth government agencies, involved in these areas of welfare service delivery.

It needs to be noted that a very large proportion of this work is carried out by volunteers. Volunteers and voluntary agencies have a long and honoured record in this country in the delivery of welfare services. As noted in this report, in many areas of welfare service delivery, volunteers rather than paid employees are the key human resource. It has been estimated that 10 per cent of the population 15 years and over contribute an average of 74 hours each year to providing social welfare services to the community. We must consider the role of volunteers on two levels: firstly, their contribution to our community and, secondly, the enhancement of lifestyle and wellbeing experienced by the volunteer. One of the best examples is the 70-plus-year-old delivering meals on wheels or home library services to the oldies. We heard of plenty of these marvellous workers along our way.

Dilemmas facing the committee were the high proportion of anecdotal evidence and the level of fear and suspicion of competition tendering, coupled with the difficulty in obtaining hard evidence of where it has been used and gone wrong. Nevertheless, when governments or parliaments go out and seek the opinion of the community when considering a range of policy options, surely those working in the specific areas do have valid opinions to be heard and considered. I believe, in the final outcome, that those opinions, views and fears have, in the main, been taken into account in this report.

Some of the views put to the committee were most convincing and thoughtful. What reaction would we see to the level of volunteerism should profit come into the equation? If the smaller community based organisations, where much policy innovation has been evident over the years, have to compete for contracts on a commercial basis with larger companies, will they find them selves on an even playing field? Probably not when you consider evidence to date that the actual cost of preparing tender documents is absorbed by the organisation itself, not included as a component of the tender. The fear that the smaller organisation will battle is a valid one.

We heard many examples of where an organisation had gone to the cost of entering more than one tender at a time and then having to wait months for the outcome while carrying those costs. What will happen to the current situation of cooperation between community based organisations when their financial existence will depend on competing against one another for the dollars in those contracts? Will they be able to happily share ideas and experiences, as they have done in the past? I think one of the most difficult questions posed to us was: how do you write into a tender document that the paid employee of the successful contracting organisation is expected to care, to take that little bit of extra time and concern which the volunteer unquestioningly delivers? Paid time is not the consideration; care for the client is.

There is no doubt that there are some people around who believe there is little we cannot competitively tender out in the area of government service delivery. I do not happen to subscribe to that view. In fact, I believe the time has come for us all to prescribe utmost caution, and I believe this report does that.

We also offer some suggestions for processes where standards, accountability and so on are concerned. However, the bottom line is really pretty simple. When considering the lives of the less advantaged in our society, do we allow consideration of competition to dominate, to let market forces start to take hold some time in the future? We can set down these paths with the greatest faith and intent and with what we believe may be the highest level of standard and accountability settings. These things should be, and already are, in place in the current delivery systems. But they can always be improved and better developed, and evidence to our committee strongly urged for that to continue.

You do not have to go down the competitive tendering path to ensure higher standards, accountability or value for the dollar. I worry that, should we at some stage in the future adopt this approach, with profit being a major component in the delivery of these services, we will see an erosion of quality or commitment as workers are asked to do more with less, with increased case loads and responsibilities being loaded onto them.

While some areas of government service have already adopted the competitive tendering approach, and employment services is an obvious one that comes to mind, I repeat this report's note of caution and I draw particular attention to two recommendations. Recommendation 1 reads:

The Committee recommends that the government agency remains accountable for efficient and effective delivery of services, irrespective of whether welfare services are provided to clients by government agencies or through a contractor.
Recommendation 8, which follows on from a number of recommended steps of action, reads:
Further development of competitive tendering processes should not proceed until such an approach is adoptedâ
in that way referring to those steps of action.

In conclusion, I want to place on record my thanks to the chair of this committee, the member for Mallee, Mr John Forrest, who guided this inquiry through some difficult times. To those parliamentary colleagues who involved themselves in what I believe was an important inquiry, thank you for your debate, your consideration and your assistance. To the committee secretariat, committee secretary Bjarne Nordin, along with Darren Benham, Nicola Mizen and Belinda Shepherd, my thanks for your assistance and guidance.

In the short amount of time left, I would like to refer to a particular quote in the report. It a was a piece of evidence given, verbally adhering, from the Lake Macquarie and Newcastle HACC Forum. They argued:

Service providersâthe organisation and the personnelâwill inevitably change with closure of contracts. The HACC client group are vulnerable and it is not in their best interest to lose continuity of care and established relationships with service providers. The way in which services are delivered to frail aged people and people with disabilities is vitally important to their wellbeing.

I think that captures, more than I would wish, the sentiments I am putting to the report. I join my colleagues in recommending this report and I look forward to the government's consideration of its comments and its recommendations.

talk.start.para: âIt is very pleasing to stand and to speak, as the chairman of the committee, to the tabling of this report. I would also like to very quickly place my appreciation on the record to the member for Lilley (Mrs Elizabeth Grace) for making the tabling statement earlier this day on my behalf. This is an extremely busy place, Mr Deputy Speaker Hollis, as you know, given that I am supposed to be sitting where you are sitting right now, in accordance with the timetable. Shortly I will be sitting where you are sitting and you will be where I am.

speech.para: The tabling of committee reports is a good opportunity for the parliament to demonstrate to the broad community just how busy members are out of the public profileâoutside the mainstream, if you likeâin terms of the hard work that goes into collecting the evidence that forms the basis of committee reports. I am very pleased to have a hardworking group of members on the committee who traipse around the nation, asking the right questions, the penetrating questions which put the evidence on the record that enables them to then write a report such as that which we have tabled today.

The committee has been very active in the last little while. Last year we tabled a report on youth suicide and had a very favourable, prompt response from the government, with all of our recommendations being adopted. We had a men's health report also. Both of these reports came from a different procedure of the committee. Rather than a formal inquiry, we held one-day seminars and asked all of the participants to come here and to record their contributions in Hansard, which speeds up the determination of recommendations. It is a procedure which I would like to suggest to other chairs of committees. We await a response on that men's health report as well.

Last year we also produced a report on concession cards in an effort to get some rationalisation into the seven Commonwealth cards that are endemic through the social security system and the social welfare system. One other report that I am very proud of was on telemedicine. We currently await a response from the government on those two reports. I would urge prompt consideration of those two very important reports. I understand the difficulty in forming a resolution because they involve a huge number of departments and portfolios, but that telemedicine report in particular is an opportunity to deliver to regional Australia acute health care and primary health care.

I know I am a little off track and need to speak specifically to this report, but I mention those to indicate just how busy our committee has been in the last two years. The report that we are noting today relates to an issue that was referred to the committee by the Minister for Health and Family Services (Dr Wooldridge) in April last year. So in the short space of 12 months we have been able to collect the evidence, get it on the record and make some punchy recommendations.

As the member for Namadgi (Ms Ellis) commented, the inquiry was interesting in that it noted the different stages at which the process of competitive tendering proceeds and, given that, the nature of our inquiry caused us to inquire into state delivered, as well as commonwealth delivered, welfare servicesâalthough the great bulk of them, of course, are delivered by state agencies. It is interesting to note that $9 billion a yearâthat is something like two per cent of our gross domestic productâis the amount expended to around 11,000 community based and church affiliated organisations and numerous other private for-profit and not-for-profit companies. So it was interesting in the inquiry to have the discussions and collect information from all those agencies.

Probably the most profound recommendation that the report makes is in consideration of whether a particular service ought to be subjected to this process of competitive tendering in the first place. Much of what the committee became aware of during the inquiry was somewhat anecdotal, and there was no specific negative which we could embrace. But there was the fear that to have a process of competition amongst the voluntary sector of community based organisations would put us back 10 years. In fact, it is interesting to note that, if the hours of work mentioned by the member for Namadgi are translated into real dollars, the contribution of the volunteer sectorâthat is, people motivated by their strong sense of community to be involved in not-for-profit organisationsâis measured in billions of dollars. That is something we do not want to undermine. If we attempt to undermine that, we ought to be very careful. The report takes great pains to alert the parliament to that danger.

Leading on from that, we discovered that, in defining services in terms of their potential to be subjected to the process, there needs to be an overriding `continuum of contestability'âand it is a dreadfully bureaucratic sort of termâand we make a very strong recommendation in our report that all welfare service delivery processes should have some overriding definition about their capacity to be subjected to a contestability approach. I think, if that framework were in place, the community would be a lot more comfortable about this process.

We discovered some very good news about the provision of new services, particularly those delivered by the Department of Veterans' Affairs, being initiated in regional and provincial parts of the nation. When the department was initiating a new service, it would become a very natural process as it was not known who was out there able to become involved in tenderingâand not necessarily tendering in the strictest sense of the word that we have come to know, particularly as considered by someone whose whole professional career has been associated with the tendering of major contracts.

We have evolved a modification, if you like, of the old submission based process where there might be $150,000 worth of funding available, but the tender process is to say, `Well, that's the amount of money. Would you tender and explain to us how you would deliver this service, and justify to us that you can deliver the quality and the efficiency within the time frames, rather than give us a price for the service.' That is a sort of modification of the old-fashioned submission based process that used to occur in the past.

Essentially, the report calls for caution. It says, `Let us approach this whole subject sensibly.' There are some positives, but there are some dangers if it is not done properly. I hope that the government will accept the recommendations in this report. I hope that it will heed of that warning and instigate the recommendations we are making about some form of continuum that gives the community some confidence that at the end of the day it will not see an erosion of the services it has come to expect.

I would just close my remarks by offering my appreciation to all the members of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Family and Community Affairs. The committee has 14 participating members. I express particular appreciation to the Deputy Chairman, the member for Franklin (Mr Harry Quick), and all the other members. I offer very special appreciation to Bjarne Nordin, the committee secretary, who faithfully organises the inquiries and gets the right people in the right place at the right time. A very special thanks also goes to Dr Darren Benham, who was seconded to us but who, as inquiry secretary, has given us excellent support in the coordination and collection of evidence and in the detailed preparation of the report. Special thanks goes to the senior research officer, Nicola Mizen, and also to the administrative officer, Belinda Shepherd. I commend this report to the House and to all members for their reading, understanding and appreciation. I look forward to a hasty response from the government.

talk.start.para: âAs a member of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Family and Community Affairs, I am pleased to speak on this report. The competitive tendering of government services is a concept that is generally worthy of support. Certainly, we have long held the belief that, if a private organisation can deliver a range of services more efficiently and cost effectively than the public sector, it makes sense to allow it to do so. Of course, in such cases it is crucial that the government sets criteria that must be met and continues to monitor and ensure that the services are being delivered in a way that is beneficial for the community. However, as we found during the course of this inquiry, the welfare sector is unique and there are serious questions about some aspects of the contracting out of services, particularly competitive tendering.

speech.para: Welfare services are a growing sector. In 1995-96, $8.9 billion was spent on providing welfare services, which is an increase of 89 per cent since 1989-90. Of this, 65 per cent is provided by state, federal and local government, 10 per cent by non-government welfare organisations and 35 per cent by clients. This report's main recommendation is that no further contracting out of welfare services should take place until a continuum of contestability framework is devised to allow us to properly judge the suitability of certain services for contracting out. As I said, the welfare sector is a unique one. Australians are generous by nature, and I understand that on a per capita basis we make the largest contribution to charities of any country in the world. Those who cannot afford to donate money or goods donate their services in a voluntary capacity. We are a great nation of volunteers. It is estimated that 10 per cent of the population aged over 15 donate an average of 74 hours each year to social welfare organisations.

I am pleased to say that we have more than our fair share of these big-hearted people in my electorate of Forde. In fact, each year I recognise the hard work of local voluntary workers with a Forde contribution award, which is a very positive way of thanking local residents, many of whom are elderly and have a lifetime of service to the community. One of the reasons we are hesitant about the implementation of competitive tendering on welfare services is that it has the potential to greatly affect our voluntary workers. If we change the nature of our welfare sector towards competitiveness, the dollar becomes the bottom line, the charities and community organisations become businesses and then it seems inevitable that these groups will appear much less attractive to volunteers.

Any decrease in voluntary workers would mean increased costs for welfare agencies, and there is a very real possibility that this would far outweigh the financial benefits it may gain. What is more, voluntary work is a very crucial way of life for many people, particularly those who are retired. It keeps them active, it ensures they continue to be a productive part of our community, and the enormous benefits of both these things in terms of their health is simply immeasurable. As a government, we have taken action to actively encourage the participation of people in voluntary work. Our changes to the social security system reflect this.

This report discussed the pros and the cons of further contracting out of welfare services, and it clearly shows that more definitive examination is required before we rush headlong into further contracting out of these services. As someone who has worked with the disabled and many local community organisations, I believe it is very wise to be cautious about going too far. We certainly need to set in place strict guidelines, and every organisation needs to be totally accountable for the distribution of funds and the outcomes they receive. Competition is a great thing in nearly every respect but, when it comes to people based and people driven sectors such as welfare, it is impossible to judge assistance in mere dollar terms.

The report summarises a very diverse funding institution in Australia that covers six different models, and they cover over 11,000 community based church affiliated organisations. Welfare services are spread over a very diverse range of services which include: aged care; disability services; community, individual and family services as well as child-care; and employment programs. It is very difficult to measure the precise nature of all of these groups due to the lack of data, and I am sure my committee members agree that there is a very urgent need for resources to be provided so that the data collection is up to date and readily available.

Larger organisations, such as the Salvation Army, Red Cross, Centacare and Anglicare, run their establishments like a business with large numbers of paid professional staff plus volunteers. They also have a substantial investment and infrastructure. But the majority of our welfare organisations have rather small annual budgets of less than $100,000, and they are mainly staffed by volunteers. They are specialised groups providing unique services in local communities, and many providers voiced their concerns about competitive tendering which could lead to the demise of their volunteers and support groups. It also highlights the many disadvantages of regional and rural Australian service providers.

Key recommendations by the committee were that the government agencies remain totally accountable for the efficient delivery of services irrespective of whether welfare services are provided to clients by government agencies or through contractors. This was reiterated by the New South Wales government and the Department of Veterans' Affairs, which said in their submissions that they were concerned about that. I found it to be a very interesting inquiry because it covered many more aspects than I ever would have believed possible at the beginning of this inquiry. Some of those concerns that we heard included: the impact of service quality; the national competition policy; the continuity of service delivery; the impacts of the costs of services; the cost of impacts on government, service providers and consumers; sector reform; employment impacts; and interagency relationships.

A valid statement was made by a social worker from Toowoomba, and I would like to read out a section. I would have found exactly the same thing with this particular statement if I were still working for disabled people. The social worker said:

Competitive tendering may be diverse because organisations will be set against each other in competing for funding. At present, a valued characteristic of community organisations is their ability to work cooperatively together sharing resources and sharing their knowledge. This is for two reasons: the value base of the community sector which involves working for the common good but also because insufficient funding has necessitated pooling resources to make the most of what is available. If survival is at stake in a competitive tendering process, there will be an incentive to play the cards much closer to one's chest, and the growth, knowledge and skills in our community sector development depends on the sharing of knowledge and the transfer of skills.
That really hit home to me, because I know that is what they survive on out in the community.

In closing, I would like to thank my fellow parliamentary committee members, especially our chairman, Mr Forrest, for the joint cooperation during the report, and the secretariatâMr Nordin, Dr Benham, Miss Mizen and Ms Shepherdâfor their support during the inquiry and for preparing a professional final report reflecting the many concerns we have heard during the inquiry. I also extend my thanks to the community groups, government bodies and interest groups for their submissions and appearance at our hearings. It is their recommendations and their thoughts that we have reported in What price competition? I commend this report to the House and strongly support the idea that no further contracting out take place until this is examined in much more detail.

talk.start.para: âThis is an unusual way of handling parliamentary reports, but I certainly appreciate that we have more time this evening than we have perhaps at the normal tabling time. At the outset, I would like to place on record my appreciation of the secretariat of the committee: Mr Nordin, Dr Benham, Ms Mizen and Ms Shepherd. Often in our speeches we put secretariat staff last and often they get left off the end, so it is very important to indicate up front our appreciation of their hard work and their contribution.

speech.para: I would like to quote from page xi of the report to give a context to this inquiry:

At the outset, the Committee wishes to emphasise that the overwhelming weight of evidence suggests that no further contracting out of welfare services should take place until a continuum of contestability framework is developed for determining the suitability of these services for contracting out. This framework should include service related and non-service related factors and be reviewed on a regular basis to take account of changes in organisational objectives and practices, technology and service markets, and that the contestability status of all welfare services be re-assessed at regular intervals.

I wanted to quote that at this point because it is very important that we get a context of how the committee concluded this inquiry. During the process we had something like 169 or 170 submissions. We had 10 days of hearings in various parts of the country. I know it may be fashionable to think that parliamentarians and the parliamentary process do not represent and reflect so-called mainstream Australia, but anybody who looks at this report will understand that, given an opportunity, parliamentarians can work productively and can certainly be a useful conduit to convey not simply the concerns or fears of the community but also constructive ideas and solutions from the community back to government.

This is an extremely important inquiry and it has been run by the parliamentary committee in parallel with a second inquiry, which I will touch on later in my speech, on indigenous health. At the same time we have been running two inquiries: one on contracting out of welfare services and competitive tendering, the other on the circumstances of the health of indigenous AustraliansâAboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders. That was perhaps coincidental, but there were certainly a lot of cross-referencing and cross-fertilising between those two inquiries. It is very important to realise that, with 14 committee members, this report is unanimous.

I notice that Mr Deputy Speaker Forrest is now in the chair. He was the chair of the committee and I pay him my respects and my appreciation for his work in ensuring that this report is bipartisan and has the support of all members. That gives the lie to the common perception that we spend our time arguing with each other over silly points of order and matters of a trivial nature. The fact is that we spend most of our time trying to develop solutions that we can all live with and understand. This report, perhaps more than most, embodies that.

The inquiry dealt with the contracting out of welfare services, which covers such a wide range of activities, from the very large contracts for health through to very small contracts for home care, for home help in a small communityâa tremendous range of organisations, services and personnel. To try to find a national approach so that the methodology used is both appropriate and productive is not an easy task. In fact, in some ways, the report effectively says that: there is not any one single solution, but there may be an approach.

Perhaps the issue is more the approach that is taken than the precise formula that is used. What you do in one part of the country you may do slightly differently elsewhere, but you would use a similar approach. The report establishes a technique or term called a continuum of contestability. It is an unusual way of thinking about it. But the concept essentially says that, rather than having a tender each year where there are winners and losers, where there is competition, where there is nastiness, where they may be lack of propriety, where there may be all kinds of problems involved, where organisations may be destroyed and services may be disrupted, we look at providing the services on a continuing basis but make sure that that continuing basis is good for the people being serviced and for the people providing it.

Simply letting a tender or having a competitive tender is not necessarily the best way of getting a service. The price being put forward by the tenderer may not reflect the cost. The organisation may go broke. It happens in all kinds of worlds. It happens in the commercial world and it will happen in the welfare world as well when the outcome may be much worse for the clients and for governments. We need a process that may allow the state or federal departments which are letting contracts in the welfare field to have a process that will allow them to evaluate and constantly monitor to ensure that the services being provided are cost effective and, most importantly, suit the person that they are there for.

There is a danger that organisations may become self-serving: serving their own organisational interests rather than the interests of their consumers. There is a danger that governments and departments may become remote and too officious and, again, lessen the quality of the service or be not sufficiently sharp to ensure that the funds are well spent; in other words, waste can easily occur. The concept being put forward in the report is more to develop a process that allows or ensures that contracts are being checked and monitored. Quite frankly, if those things are being done then the price should not vary; it should not cost any more for organisation A than organisation B, if they are doing the same work with the same standard and with the same benchmarks involved. The difference, of course, is that in different towns and with different sizes of services, costs could vary enormously. There is a great danger that we could let a national contract for home care or for nursing and yet the cost in a country town could be double or treble that in a city because of the cost of travel or because of the cost of overheads involved.

The idea of a national pricing structure is not appropriate. It invariably would not work because Australia does not have a common cost structure in the various parts of the country. But a common process could work and the committee, Mr Deputy Speaker, as you know, is trying to put forward a series of recommendations that will help strengthen organisations and help improve services.

We see competition in more than one light when it becomes winner take all and when it becomes a question of secrets, non-sharing and non-collaboration, as it clearly would and has been, to some extent, in the welfare field. That kind of competition is not productive. Our welfare sector relies a great deal on volunteers, community effort and community involvement. You do not achieve that by making them wage war on each other on a price basis. We heard of case after case where organisations were headhunting staff, where people who wrote submissions were highly valued and where the cost of submissions alone was taking up substantial parts of the organisation's budget.

Rather than providing a service, money was being used to actually write submissions for the next tender or for the next contract, so the whole point of the operation was actually shifted away from providing the service to being a good submission writer and a good tendererâwhich does not necessarily say that you would be a good service provider. Mixed up in all this is this question about purchaser and provider. The government is a purchaser of services and how those services are provid ed. The difficulty between those two roles, I think, is now well understood by this committee, as are the many other facets of service provision.

The comments that came forward from across the community were extremely pertinent. In fact, on page 39 onwards we talk in detail about that. Witnesses said that competitive tendering had the capacity to undermine the effective working relationship between the contracting agencies and the non-government service deliverers. In other words, in many cases there is more than one layer. The government will let a contract to a provider who, in turn, will let it out further. The way that works between the organisations can be quite destructive for community relationships.

I referred previously to the other inquiry that we are currently undertaking and which we think we may not finish before this parliament is prorogued. It is to do with the question of Aboriginal health. I want to touch on it simply because it is very pertinent to this inquiry. What is put forward in this report will have relevance and meaning in that inquiry and for those services as well.

More importantly, I want to make this point because the chance may not occur again. The issue of Aboriginal health is one that has been a vexed issue for so long in this countryâ100 years or more. It is one that we have grappled with as people and as governmentsâboth state and federalâacross the country of all persuasions. Our achievements as a nation are not something to be proud of but we are currently in the middle of an inquiry which has been going on now for some months in which parliamentarians from the three main parties have actually been working as one. We are setting an example, I trust and I am sure, for the community and for all governments, that there can be a bipartisan approach to some of the most difficult questions facing the countryâand this is one of the most difficult.

In doing this, we may encourage others who are involved in either receiving services or being involved in providing services at whatever level to recognise that, until we do treat it as a national issue with a bipartisan approach, we will not be helping. From the point of view of those of us on the committeeâand what I am saying now we have said on the record previously, Mr Deputy Speaker, so I am not making a comment that previously has not been said but I think has been largely unrecognised, except for those who have been fortunate enough to be at the hearingsâI particularly want to express my appreciation to the committee members and to you, Mr Deputy Speaker, for the fact that we have been working in this way.

At the end of this inquiry, I do not quite know what we will get but I think the process we are going through is infinitely valuable to us, as individual parliamentarians, and potentially to governments across the country and to community workers who despair that this situation will ever be improved. To have the number of people who have worked so long and so hard in this field, with so little success, is distressing, to say the least. To maintain their morale and their spirit, and to encourage them to keep going, will require an enormous effort on the part of our committee, but that effort is going in in a joint way. We are saying we are here to address the problems as federal parliamentarians, not as members of particular parties.

For those who are observing the inquiryâand there were some people who were sceptical; and I must confess I shared some of the scepticism at the start of the inquiryâlet me say that I have found to date that my personal understanding has improved enormously and I now have some genuine hope that we may help to make a difference. We may not fully solve the problem but, between the example we are setting for governments and parliamentarians across the country to see that we can do this if we try and the hope it may give those involved in providing services and those who need the services, it will be seen that there is a genuine effort being made to address these problems.

Those two parts make this inquiry a very seminal inquiry. There is a concern that we cannot finish it before the parliament is prorogued. Committee members have all said that, in the next parliament, regardless of who is in power, any of us who are back on that committee will carry that inquiry forward in the same way and achieve an outcome that we have worked towards. The competitive tendering inquiry and the Aboriginal health inquiry have had the capacity to change the way we do things in this country. I think the competitive tendering inquiry will do that, without doubt, and I am pleased to have been part of it. The Aboriginal health inquiry has the potential to do that and I trust that, in the months ahead, before or after the election, when we finish that inquiry, it will also be seen as contributing to the improved governance of welfare services for a particular group. I commend the report to the House.
Debate (on motion by Mr Dondas) adjourned.

subdebateinfo.title: Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade Committee

talk.start.para: âI have only a few moments to finish my remarks on the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade report entitled Australia's trade relationship with IndiaâCommonwealth, common language, cricket and beyond . Two significant events occurred during the final stages of the committee's inquiry which impact on the Australia-India relationship. The first was the election of a new government in March 1998 and the second was the five underground nuclear tests conducted in May of 1998. India has been described as a country with no full stops and the latter event has put a comma in the Australia-India relationship at both a political and commercial level. The committee maintains that Australia must continue to develop its links west and to build on its trade and investment relationship with India.

speech.para: In conclusion, I would like to take a few moments of the House to thank all members of the Trade Subcommitteeâin particular, the member for Chifley (Mr Price), who was the deputy chair; the member for Throsby (Mr Hollis); Senator Kerry O'Brien; the member for Aston (Mr Nugent); and the member for Groom (Mr Taylor)âand Joanne Towner, who is the secretary to the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade, and more particularly the subcommittee secretary, Jane Vincent, and her secretariat staff, Miss Elena Hull, Julia Morris and John Merrill. It was certainly a very time consuming report to go through page by page. I do thank all those members who took part in the final deliberations. I commend the report to the House.

talk.start.para: âAt the outset let me say that I personallyâand I know the members of the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade do as wellâappreciate very much those many members of the community who came before our committee and shared their knowledge and their experience of Australia-India trade with us. We also received expert advice from many government departments and academics. We were fortunate that His Excellency the Indian High Commissioner, accompanied by the Deputy High Commissioner, came before the committee and gave a very stimulating submission. The High Commissioner's knowledge and involvement with both Australia and India made his a very valuable contribution.

speech.para: Mr Deputy Speaker Forrest, it was you yourself when speaking to an earlier report who said that that report was a good example of parliamentary committees working together. I would endorse that remark very much with this committee. In this chamber the standard and the work of members of parliament are under constant spotlight and scrutinyâoften rather unfavourablyâand so many people judge members of parliament by what goes on in question time. What they do not know and what they do not see is the work that goes on in committees and subcommittees around this parliament.

I have served on many committees in my many years in this parliament and they have all been bipartisan. Members of parliament from all sides of the political fence who work on those committees work together and work for the good of Australia. Maybe it is a fact that we do not get very much time to debate committee reports in this chamber and, unless it is something startling or exciting, the media does not show a lot of attention to them. If we in this committee are lucky, we might get a couple of lines in the Financial Review. It will obviously be covered in some of the trade reports. The 18 months or so that the committee members worked on that committee and worked as a team to bring down a significant report will largely go unnoticed and unsung.

This important report on Australia's trade relations with India has to some extent been overtaken by events, as the Chairman of the Trade Subcommittee, the member for the Northern Territory (Mr Dondas), said, not least by India's recent underground explosions of nuclear devices. For many of us who have a long-term interest and a great affection for India, this was an incident of great regret. In my view, India needed no such show to guarantee her place in the world. India has got an important place in the world and that place will grow in importance and stature. There was no need for her to prove her worth, as it were, by these nuclear explosions.

Despite the immense problems, the Indian economy over the last few years has made important progress. It is a great pity that this progress should be placed in jeopardy because India felt it necessary to prove her credentials of greatness to the international community. It should be of great concern that the amount of aid, the technical assistance, that India was receiving has been curtailed. It is true to say that there is at the moment a certain coolness in the relationship between our two countries. I hope that this coolness will evaporate because on an individual level there is a tremendous amount of goodwill between the peoples of our two countries.

When most Australians think of India, the portrait they have in their mind is one of begging and poverty. There is poverty in India, but this is only part of the picture. How could it be otherwise with a population of 950 million where it is estimated that 328 million citizens live below the poverty line? People often do not realise that India has a middle class of between 80 million and 150 millionâand this depends on what statistics you want to useâwho have a disposable income as high as in Australia. It is essential that we play our part in exporting to, and working with, that market.

We sometimes agonise about breaking into markets around the worldâmarkets of 30, 40 or 50 million peopleâbut India is a huge market for us, one ignored for far too long. Our trade has expanded over recent years, but to nowhere near the levels it should have. The expanding trade relationship has been provided by the gradual restructuring of India's formerly inward looking economy. Since the early 1990s, a wide range of economic and trade measures have been improved to open up the Indian economy. The current governmentâthe BJP-led coalitionâhas indicated its commitment to keeping this progress going.

Despite its status as a developing country, financial and investment indicators suggest India has huge potential as a market for trade in goods and services. It is the world's largest democracy, with a population of approximately 950 million people, and is growing at two per cent per annum. In 1994, it was rated as the fifth largest economy in the world in purchasing power parity terms, although it is estimated that, as I said before, some 328 million citizens are living below the poverty line. The size and real disposable income of India's growing middle class is debated. However, what is not debated is that, by the year 2020, India is expected to be the fourth largest economy in the world.

We hope in this report to give important direction to Australians looking to do business with India. Of course, as with any relationship, it has to be worked at. It is not enough for us to talk to the Indians about cricket and hockey alone. There is much more that we have in common. This was shown at the Australia-India New Horizons promotion held in 1996. In fact, reports I have received indicate that, so popular was the promotion, at times it led to somewhat of an embarrassment when people were overbooked at events. But there is no doubt that the program was a success in the exchange of knowledge of business and trade opportunities between the two countries.

There have always been significant academic and educational links between Australia and India. Many Indian students are now studying at our educational centres. Butâand this was put to the committee at one of our hearingsâit is important that we do not just look to India as a source of paying students, but as a source of a meaningful exchange of academics between our two countries.

One of the things that came up in this inquiry also came up in other inquiries recently: the closure of Radio Australia's transmitter at Cox Peninsula, just outside Darwin. The transmitter was closed as a budgetary measure. I believe it was a poorly thought out decision. That transmitter served a very important function not only for the Indian subcontinent but other parts of the world. For example, during the recent problems in Indonesia, Australians could not get any direct news as a result of that transmitter being closed down. We hope that the government will reconsider that decision. As we say in the report, it is a matter of concern that a budgetary decision made by the Australian government for a saving of a mere $1.6 million within the National Transmission Agency has resulted in the loss of an invaluable means of profiling Australia and furthering our interests in India.

Another issue that we dealt with is child labour. I see the honourable member for Scullin (Mr Jenkins) in the chamber. He would be very familiar with this issue because he and I were part of a delegation to India some time ago. It is an important issue. India acknowledges that it is a problem. Reports vary about how many young people are involved. I have seen reports that up to 17 million people are involved. It is an extremely complex issue. I know that many people say that if children do not work the family do not eat, and things like that, but I think it is an important issue that India has got to look at very closely. Of course, we need not single out India; child labour occurs in many parts of the world. Quite frankly, wherever it is occurring it should be highlighted. I believe that Australia, like Germany and the United States, should have some form of certification for goods that come into this country saying that they are not made by child labour. I know that there are all sorts of problems relating to how authentic and how respected that certification would be. Nevertheless, I think that Australia should have a stronger voice on the whole subject of child labour.

India is a major destination for Australian diamondsâwhere they are cut and polishedâbut this trade is not reflected in the two-way trade figures between the two countries. The diamonds are not shipped directly to India, but go through Antwerp. It has been said that, if the diamonds were shipped directly to India, which the Indians want, that would increase the published trade between our two countries. Recently, I was fortunate enough to be briefly in India. When I was there I met with Commerce Minister Hegde. One of the issues that we discussed was the diamond trade. I was left in no doubt that India would like to trade directly with Australia and include this trade in our trading figures, rather than the diamonds going through Antwerp as they do now.

Relations between Australia and Indiaâin trade and socially and culturallyâwill, over the coming months, have to be repaired. I would hope that our relationship is one that is mature enough to withstand the differences of opinion which inevitably will emerge. I think it is true to say that there was a certain amount of disappointment on the committee and that its spirits were dampened when, after working so hard, for so long and having had quite positive input, the underground nuclear devices were exploded. This aside, I hope that many in Australia and India will read this report with interest in order to increase our mutual potential. Just as Australia is not a land of endless beaches, nor is India just a land of poverty and mysticism. India is a vibrant country and we have much to offer each other in the areas of trade and cultural and social exchanges.

I wish to pay tribute to the two chairmen of this committee: firstly, the Hon. Ian Sinclair, now the Speaker, who chaired the inquiry until March this year and, secondly, the current chair, the member for the Northern Territory, the Hon. Nick Dondas, who showed leadership and took over the duties with great diligence and skill. The report is, I believe, a tribute to these skills.

While in a congratulatory mood, I also pay tribute to the deputy chair, my colleague and friend the Hon. Roger Price. Also, thanks go to the committee secretariat: Elena Hull, Julia Morris and John Merrill. As always, so much of the writing of the report and the strength of the report goes to the secretary. Jane Vincent carried out her duties excellently in this regard. My congratulations to each of them.

I believe that we have brought down a realistic report which will, I am sure, enhance the relations between India and Australia. Our recommendations are practical and realistic. I hope that the report will be read with interest by all those who have an interest in trade between Australia and India. Most importantly, I hope that the report will enhance that important sphere of trade between our two great countries.

talk.start.para: âIt gives me great pleasure as a member of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade to speak on Australia's trade relationship with IndiaâCommonwealth, common language, cricket and beyond . I would certainly echo the comments of the previous speaker, the honourable member for Throsby (Mr Hollis). In particular, I would echo his comments of commendation of both the chairs who were there during the course of the preparation of this report and also the staff, who play such an important role in any report that is produced in this parliament.

speech.para: India is a country that we have all heard about, but I suspect that many Australians have flown over it but have not stopped off on the way to somewhere else, often to Europe. I have to confess that until a couple of years ago I was in that situation. Then a couple of years ago I made my first ever visit to India as part of a parliamentary delegation. We went to New Delhi and we went to Mumbai, better known as Bombay, and then we went to Bangalore, the Silicone Valley of India.

Whilst a number of the stereotypes that you pick up during the course of your life, whether you are reading or whether you are watching television, were certainly the case, equally you get a whole new perspective. Yes, the poverty is there and yes, the Taj Mahal is magnificent and yes, the dust and the bullock carts and all those things are thereâthe traditional picture of Indiaâbut I do not think we understand at all the size of the population. When you talk about nearly a billion people it is meaningless until you actually go and see the vast numbers of people everywhere you turn.

I do not think we have an appreciation of much of the technology of India or of the large numbers of educated people who are in India. When you are talking about a population of 900 million you do not have to have a very large percentage of the population to have very large numbers of people with university degreesâhighly educated, highly literate, highly skilled and competent people. In our country we could have 80 or 90 per cent of our population with degrees and we would still have only a fraction of the number of highly qualified people in India, where perhaps one or two per cent have degrees. It is the scale of the exercise that I think hits you when you go to that country.

I was there shortly before the New Horizons program that the previous speaker alluded to. That New Horizons program was a major push by the Australian government to, if you like, sell Australia in the Indian context. As you travel around India it is surprising how little people in India actually know about our country. In the same way that we have stereotyped images of India, they have stereotyped images of us. Probably one of the few things that we think we have in common is cricket. At the time I was there it was not a good time to be a supporter of Australian cricket. Nevertheless, we held our end up, so to speak. One of the first things we need to understand about doing trade with another countryâand India is one of those that is going to be much more important in the trade sense in years to comeâis that we have to learn more about the country. And they need to learn more about us. That means that we need to tear down the barriers that separate the two countries.

It is quite a long way to travel to India. It is not just five or eight hours up the road, like most of the South East Asia. It is twice as far in travelling time. That makes it just that little bit harder to get there. Until a year or so ago, not too many flights, particularly Qantas flights, went from here to India. By and large you tended to overfly it a great deal. If you do not understand how business is done in a country, then you are less likely to be successful. If you do not understand about the standard of living, if you do not understand about the problems of transport, if you do not understand about the problems of hygiene, if you do not understand about the huge market that everybody talks aboutâbut 90-odd per cent of the people probably cannot afford to buy the product we might produceâthen you do not have an understanding of what the market is all about and what the real opportunities are.

There are something like 80,000 millionaires in India, and there are 200 or 300 million who are what we would call in the middle class. That swamps this country in terms of numbers. So it is an attractive market. India has thrown off its past association with places like Russia. The signs, when you travel around, are quite visible. All the government cars are 30-year-old Russian cars. They do not work terribly well, the springs are not very good and obviously a lot of updating has to go on. But as India throws off that past and starts to develop itself, to open up and to get into the open market of the world economy, there are going to be tremendous opportunities because of the size of that population.

It is not sufficient to do what we did with New Horizons and have just one short-term pitch at the market. We spent $6 million on New Horizons as a promotional pitch, but we went to only six different cities and it lasted only a few short weeks. The reality of life is that if you are going to be in a market you have to be there all the time; you have to be right across the market; you have to be reinforcing your message on an ongoing basis. As a country we do not do that enough. So some of the recommendations in this report talk about the need for more promotion and the need to get ourselves in the market much more frequently and on a much wider basis.

I noticed another thing when I was there and we had the opportunity to meet with the then Indian Prime Minister; there have been a couple of changes sinceâIndia certainly has a robust democracy. When we met the Indian Prime Minister he was very keen that our Prime Minister (Mr Howard) make a visit. In a lot of countries the fact that political leaders pay calls and make visits is an important signal regarding the significance that we might attach to those countries. So we believe, and we have said in our report, that the Prime Minister should make a visit, as should other ministers on a more regular basis.

As alluded to by the previous speaker, one of the difficulties that has overlayed the tail end of this report as we have finalised it and brought it to be tabled, is the very recent nuclear detonations by India and Pakistan. Clearly that has meant that there is some frost or chill in the relationship between Australia and India. Maybe that is an appropriate phrase to use in Canberra, which gets pretty frosty and chilly as well. The problem with that frost is that there is the danger that it may do more damage to us in some ways than to India. So whilst it is right that we express to India our disappointment and disapproval of what they have done in the nuclear field, we will see, however, economic activity between the two countries, and businesses continuing to trade and do business. If we can resolve those concerns about the nuclear issue then relations between the two countries will return to normal. This is important from a trade point of view for us and for India, and also from the point of view of the Indian population, large numbers of which live in abject poverty. They are the ones likely to suffer from any worldwide reaction or sanctions as a result of the nuclear activities.

It is not easy to do business in India. When we do business in Australia we take the infrastructure for granted. One of the heated debates in this chamber on a regular basis is about how more efficient our ports should be. In India that is not the same argument at all, whether you are talking about the railways or the airlines. Even more importantly, when it comes to roads the reality is that the infrastructure is not there. Any Australian businesses wishing to go there and do business have to understand that there is a different way of doing business. Because the infrastructure is not there you have to be much more self-sufficient. You often have to be much more patient. Things take a lot longer to get done. The bureaucracy is sometimes a thing of wonder. `Wonder' is probably not the right word because that would imply it was good. As a former British colony, India has learnt more than almost any other country in the world what being difficult and slow and bureaucratic is all about. Certainly the bureaucracy is a real problem for any country that wants to do business with India.

In our report we have made 30-odd recommendations. I would like to draw your attention to some of those. There is no time to go through all of them but some of them are quite important. Regarding the Cox Peninsula transmitter, I echo the comments of the previous speaker. When you serve on different committees in this place and undertake different inquiries on a range of areas, some issues become recurring themes. Whether you are talking about trade with India or the report I am due to speak on next, the human rights report which was also tabled today, or a range of other areas, the need to have the Cox Peninsula transmitter facility to get our voice out overseas comes back time and time again. I hope that the government can reconsider.

I have already mentioned that we thought it important that the Prime Minister make an official visit to India as soon as relations are normalised. The Minister for Trade, the member for Farrer (Mr Tim Fischer), is a very active minister for this country's interests, and travels significantly. I believe he has the respect of all the members of this House for the diligence with which he undertakes that role. We are keen for him to go to India and also to take a trade mission to coincide with the Prime Minister's visit so that we get publicity from the Prime Minister's visit and the follow up on the ground with the Minister for Trade.

We are also keen that we should look at strengthening the Austrade network across India. It is a vast country. If you are in Bangalore you cannot just pop down the road to New Delhi very easily. Because communications and other infrastructure, as I mentioned before, are not all they might be or all we are used to in this country, you need to have people on the ground. Because a lot of the business in India is to do with state governments rather than the federal government you also need that presence on the ground. So we would like to see Austrade extend its network of offices in India.

We would also like to see our government press the Indian government much more to remove a number of its tariffs and its qualitative restrictions and barriers to trade and investment which some Australian companies suffer at the moment. We also want to seeâand this crops up time after time across a range of areasâas a matter of priority, the government reintroduce some form of mixed credit or soft loan facility as part of its strategy to strengthen Australia's trade and investment performance.

Obviously, one of the difficulties we always seem to have with large countries that have a mix of good business opportunities and a large part of the population which is not very affluent is thatâon the subject of migrationâvisas are the problem. Whether it is India or China, which has a similar problem, you want to, in fact, liberalise the rules to let people come into this country to do business. The trouble is that, when you liberalise them, you open the door for a lot of people to come in who say they are coming to do business but they are actually not doing that: they look on it as a backdoor method of migration, they disappear when they get here, they become illegals and so on and so forth. That is one of the problems with opening up the immigration borders in that sense. But there is a need to look perhaps creatively at how we can perform better to make sure that the genuine business people are not deterred from coming to this country and doing business but, nevertheless, we keep out those who should not come.

We have also made a recommendation about the Australian government endorsing and actively supporting the adoption of international legal standards that combat child labour. I will finish on this point by saying that something that would horrify every member of this House are some of the child labour practices that happen in south Asia; India is not alone. When you go there, arguments are put forward to you about how economically vital it is but, on the other hand, when you see the conditions and the rate of pay, you say to yourself there must be better ways of doing it. Unless somebody takes a stand and starts to do something about it, it is likely to just drift on, so I very much hope that the Howard government will pursue that particular policy.
Debate (on motion by Mr Martin Ferguson) adjourned.

subdebateinfo.title: Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade Committee

talk.start.para: âI rise to talk about the report which was tabled this morning, Improving but. . . : Australia's regional dialogue on human rights . It is a report of the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade's subcommittee on human rights, which I have the honour to chair and of which the honourable member for Throsby (Mr Hollis) is the deputy chairman.

speech.para: The subject of Australia and human rights in the region is one which most members of this House take extremely seriously. It is an issue that is often misunderstood. It is an issue on which there are very often differences of view as to how we should go about conducting our human rights activity but, equally, there is common understanding of the goals that we are trying to achieve.

Given the location that Australia occupies in this part of the world and given the history and the nature of some of the societies of our neighbours, not just to our near north but to our north and generally in our region of the world, clearly there are sometimes conflicts between what we would call good human rights standards and those of some of our neighbours. Probably one of the outstanding things that came through in this particular inquiry was some discussion of our performance and whether we were doing as much as we could. Concerns were articulated about whether we were being as proactive, as aggressive and as active as we could be, or have been perhaps in the past, and I think there was a view that perhaps over the last 10 years Australia had not been as active as it should have been. Whether that is factually accurate or not, that is certainly the perception in some quarters. Therefore the recommendations in this report do in part encourage government to be visible and more proactive in the whole range of areas.

One of the other issues to show through as a theme in our inquiry was the current debate about Asian values. Of course, we subscribe very much to the United Nations' human rights universal standard. We take the view that human rights should be universal. Frankly, whether you are a five-year-old child here, in China, India, Indonesia, Britain or anywhere else, you are entitled to the same sort of protection as anywhere else in the world and, if people abuse five-year-olds or women or any citizen in any other way, those human rights should be universal and should be enforced universally.

That is not always accepted in some countries, particularly in some Asian countries. Dr Mahathir, the Prime Minister of Malaysia, argues that, in fact, there are Asian values which are different from the United Nations' values. He takes the view that it is not all about individual human rights.

talk.start.para: âDo you accept that?

âNo, I do not accept that. I thank the honourable member for Fisher for the interjection to make sure that I made that point clear. I do not accept that Dr Mahathir is right. I take the view that we, as individuals, are entitled to rights as individuals, whereas the Prime Minister of Malaysia will take the view that individual rights are not so important. He will take the point of view that the community is much more important than the individual and, therefore, if individuals have to suffer somewhere along the way for the greater good of the community, that is acceptable.

speech.para: I think that, once you start down that path, you get, of course, to the stage where, if you are prepared to subjugate the rights of the honourable member for Fisher (Mr Slipper) for argument's sake, really it is a short step to saying I will do the same thing to the honour able member for Batman (Mr Martin Ferguson), the honourable member for Mallee (Mr Forrest), the honourable member for Throsby (Mr Hollis) or the honourable member for Fairfax (Mr Somlyay).

So you would be on a slippery slope. It seems to me it is important that if you have a set of principles you have to stick to them.
