The following answers to questions were circulated:

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts, upon notice, on 10 March 1998:

question.para: (1) Did Optus launch Project Aurora in February 1997 claiming that it would be operational nationally before the end of 1997.
(2) Is the platform for Aurora in operation; if not, what is the reason for the delay.
(3) Is the Minister able to say whether Optus demonstrated decoders on the Aurora system at the recent Cable and Satellite Exhibition in Sydney; if so, who were the manufacturers of the decoders.
(4) Is the Minister able to say whether Optus promised that decoders for Aurora would cost $750.

(5) Is the Minister able to say (a) how many of the decoders referred to in part (3) will be available to Australian purchasers at $750, (b) from which manufacturers will Optus source the decoders it promised would cost $750 and (c) have the decoders been demonstrated on the Aurora platform.
(6) Is the Minister able to say whether the decoder price of $750 includes dealer mark-ups and distribution charges; if not, will Optus clearly state what it is undertaking in writing.
(7) On what date is the Aurora digital service expected to start in Western Australia.
(8) Is the Minister able to say whether Optus has been granted access to the Irdeto CA system; if so, why is Aurora not operational.

(9) Is the Minister able to say whether decoders need to be modified to work with the Aurora system; if so, does the relatively small market for the decoders mean that there will be a single manufacturer and no competition in the sale of the Aurora decoders.

(10) Is the Minister able to say whether Optus has advised potential viewers that it will pay for the price differential from Optus' stated price for decoders and viewers will not have to pay for receivers.
(11) Is it a fact that Galaxy retains an exclusive right to use the Irdeto CA system for pay TV in Australia.
(12) Is the Minister able to say whether Scientific Atlanta's Power-Vu system could be engineered to work with the Irdeto CA system via simulcrypt simultaneous encryption.

(13) Has the Minister's attention been drawn to distribution difficulties in the Scientific Atlanta dealer network in Western Australia during the 3 month analog and digital simulcast period; if so, is the Minister able to say whether Optus has developed a distribution strategy for its decoders.
(14) Is the Minister able to say what services Optus will be able to deliver on the Aurora platform that will not be available on the Pan Am satellite.
(15) Is the Minister able to say what other international systems are compatible with the Aurora platform.
(16) Is the Minister able to say whether Optus has a legal problem in providing access to pay TV services; if so, does Optus have a solution.

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts has provided the following answer to the honourable member's questions:

answer.para: (1) Optus announced in February 1997 the investment of $25 million on digital satellite technology, known as Aurora, and that the transition to digital operations would be completed by the end of 1997.

(2) Optus has advised that the Aurora platform is operational in that all necessary testing, trialling and other modelling has taken place. Optus has advised that there has been a delay in the commencement of services from the Aurora platform due to the initial delay in finalising the agreement for the use of a conditional access system, which offers compatibility with certain pay TV services.
(3) Optus has advised that it demonstrated decoders from the following manufacturers at the Cable and Satellite Exhibition in Sydney:
. Comstream/Panasonic
. UEC
. SunMoonStar
. Pace.
Decoders from the following manufacturers have also been demonstrated separately on the Aurora system:
. Nokia
. Hyundai
. Annan.

Optus has advised that Comstream/Panasonic and UEC have been endorsed for use on Aurora. Optus has selected the UEC decoder to replace existing analogue decoders for direct-to-home reception in the context of the digital conversion of remote area broadcasting services. Optus expects that these decoders will also be suitable for many retransmission sites. Optus is finalising arrangements in respect of retransmission sites requiring professional model decoders.

While Optus considers that selection of the UEC model is desirable to facilitate the smooth transition of viewers to digital RABS reception, it intends that other endorsed decoders will be made available in the future to increase consumer choice in accessing the range of services being developed on the Aurora platform. The UEC decoder will, of course, also be able to access these services.
(4) Optus has advised that it has not guaranteed a price of $750 for decoders.
(5) (a) Optus has advised that the recommended retail price of the UEC decoder will be $999.
(b) Optus has advised that it will be sourcing Aurora decoders from all endorsed suppliers.
(c) Yes.

(6) Optus has advised that the price of decoders represents the final cost to consumers, including the cost of the smart card, conditional access module and dealer and distribution charges. I understand that decoders used primarily for reception of remote area broadcasting services, on a non-profit basis, are exempt from sales tax.

(7) Optus has advised that it plans to commence digital services in Western Australia by the end of June 1998, but that this could be delayed until July, depending on progress with the ABC's purchase of encoders. Optus has advised that it will provide an extended dual transmission period in Western Australia, through to the mid October 1998, to minimise any disruptions to consumers.

(8) Optus has advised that it obtained permission in December 1997 for the use of the Irdeto conditional access system on the Aurora platform. The initial delay in negotiating this agreement has resulted in a consequential delay in the commencement of services from the Aurora platform.

(9) Optus has advised that there are no software problems that have required special modification of the decoders. Optus has further advised that there will be multiple suppliers and, therefore, competition in the provision of the Aurora decoders, some time after the initial RABS digital conversion.

(10) Optus has advised that it neither made, nor authorised, any official statements that it would meet any difference between the Commonwealth subsidy and the price of the decoders. Optus has further advised that it is not aware of any advice provided to the public that the company would meet any such cost difference.

(11) I understand that the rights to use the Irdeto conditional access system to deliver satellite pay TV services in Australia is currently the subject of commercial negotiation within the context of the liquidation of the assets of the Australis Media group of companies.

(12) Telstra has advised that the Scientific Atlanta PowerVu system is capable of being engineered to work with the Irdeto CA system, and that preliminary discussions on this matter have taken place between Scientific Atlanta and Irdeto. I understand that, at this stage, the two companies do not consider that there is a commercial imperative to progress integration of the CA systems.

(13) Telstra understands that there has been adequate stocks of domestic digital decoders available for sale in Western Australia since November-December 1997. Telstra has advised, however, that there was a temporary shortage of commercial decoders for retransmission sites due to the late arrival of one shipment in late February 1998, rather than mid-February as scheduled. I understand that Scientific Atlanta provided interim decoders to affected customers during this period. Telstra has also advised that there may have been some instances of delays in supply of decoders to viewers where orders were placed very late, or where some local dealers failed to act diligently in filling orders.

Optus has indicated that it accords a high priority to ensuring an adequate and consistent supply of decoders for the digital conversion of remote area broadcasting services. The company has advised that it has appointed a master distributor, Nationwide Antenna Systems, is arranging multiple distribution points in each State/Territory and direct links to a network of retailers/installers, and is ensuring the adequate availability of equipment for the commencement of digital conversions.
(14) At this stage, it is not possible to draw a final comparison between Optus and Telstra-delivered broadcasting services to remote areas in WA.

Optus has contracted to digitally transmit ABC and SBS television and radio services nationally, including local time ABC TV services in WA, and the Westlink and Horizon services. I understand that Optus has not yet reached a final decision as to what other services it might provide to RABS viewers in WA.

Telstra has contracted to digitally transmit the GWN television service in WA, and is providing companion ABC and SBS television services in local time, and has undertaken to provide all ABC radio services in WA, and the WA FM radio service.

Transmission arrangements are yet to be finalised in respect of the second commercial television service for remote and regional WA for the operation of which the Australian Broadcasting Authority (ABA) allocated a licence to WIN Television on 1 April this year.

Elsewhere in Australia, all RABS operators have contracted with Optus for the digital transmission of their services. In total, Optus has contracts for delivery on the Aurora platform of nine out of the ten RABS services, and for delivery of the Westlink, Horizon, Centrelink, CITEC and Sky Channel services.
Both Optus and Telstra have indicated that their digital decoders potentially afford access to a range of other communications services including data transfer, Internet access and pay TV.
(15) Optus has advised that satellite systems in Australia, South Africa, Continental Africa, Middle East, Thailand, Scandinavia, Greece and Eastern Europe are compatible with the Aurora platform.

(16) Optus has advised that it has neither a technical nor legal difficulty in providing a satellite based platform for the delivery of pay TV in Australia. Its Aurora decoders will potentially afford access to any pay TV service provided using the Irdeto CA system, although such a service is not currently available in remote areas.

answer.para: (1) The names and affiliations of each person who attended and received the agenda for Plant Industries Committee (PIC) meetings during 1997 are:

Higgins, CSIRO Dr Tony Gregson, National Farmers' Federation Dr George McLean/Mrs Philippa Rowland, Department of Primary Industries and Energy, Dr Ray Shorter/Dr Bryan Whan, Grains Research and Development Corporation, Mr Des Boyland, ANZECC, Dr Andina Faragher/Ms Gillian Allen/Ms Kirsty McLean, GMAC Secretariat staff.
The Terms of Reference for SCARM Working Group to Prepare `Good Agricultural Practice Guidelines for Genetically Modified Crops and Pastures' were:
(a) Prepare guidelines for the development and commercial use of genetically modified crops and pastures in Australian agriculture; and

(b) address specifically such issues as the use of herbicide-resistance genes as markers, the potential for outcrossing of transgenic plants, the deployment of these genes (herbicide-resistance, Bt and virus resistance) in rotational systems and prepare a checklist of sustainability issues.It was agreed to that the scope of the SCARM Working Group to Prepare `Good Agricultural Practice Guidelines for Genetically Modified Crops and Pastures' was to be general policies for the deployment of genes in transgenic crops such that agricultural benefits were maximised and environmental risks minimised. The Working Group was to consider the agricultural and environmental impact of genes in agricultural crops and their effects on crop systems, particularly those genes conferring insect resistance, herbicide resistance (including marker genes), virus resistance and fungus resistance.
Given this brief, this working group discussed many of the issues raised in questions 5-10 at each of the four meetings held on 10 June, 24 July, 4 September and 13 November 1997.
(3) Discussions occurred in the following committees at the following times on:

The SCARM Working Group on the Regulation of Gene Technology was the joint Commonwealth and State group responsible for examining issues associated with the regulatory system for genetically modified organisms.
(4) The committees discussed the following issues on the following numbers of occasions:
(a) the proposal for new regulations for gene technology.
(b) the proposed Gene Technology Office (GTO).
(c) the proposed Gene Technology Liaison Committee (GTLC).
Plant Industries Committee discussed (a) and (b) once in October 1997.
The SCARM GAP Working Group briefly discussed issues (a) and (b) twice, in June and November, but did not discuss (c).
(5) Discussions occurred on:
(a) the use of insect-resistant transgenic plants.
(b) the potential for insects to become resistant or tolerant to the insecticidal substances in some insect-resistant transgenic plants
The SCARM GAP Working Party discussed both issues on 10 June, 24 July, 4 September and 13 November 1997. The discussions were not connected to discussions of the new regulations for gene technology.
(6) The SCARM GAP Working Party discussed insect-resistant transgenic plants four times, at each of its meetings.
PIC 28 discussed insect-resistant transgenic plants once, at its meeting in October 1997.
(7) Discussions occurred on:
(a) the use of herbicide-resistant transgenic plants.
(b) potential problems with herbicide-resistant transgenic plants.
The SCARM GAP Working Party discussed this issue on 10 June, 24 July, 4 September and 13 November 1997.
PIC 28 discussed these issues at its meeting in October 1997.
The discussions were not connected to discussions of the new regulations for gene technology.
(8) Herbicide-resistant transgenic plants were discussed by the SCARM GAP Working Party discussed this issue on 10 June, 24 July, 4 September and 13 November 1997.

PIC 27 discussed the Commercialisation of Transgenic Crops workshop organised by the CRC for Plant Sciences and BRS in Canberra (11-13 March 1997) on 22-24 October 1996 and were presented with the workshop recommendations at PIC 28, 8-10 October 1997.
(9) Discussions were held during 1997 on:
(a) the potential for genes to be transferred between transgenic plants and other plants.
(b) potential for genetically modified plants to become weeds.
(c) use of virus-resistant transgenic plants.
(d) possible risks that may be posed by the use of virus-resistant transgenic plants.
All these issues were raised in a report to PIC in September 1995 from the BRS Workshop, entitled Herbicide-Resistant Crops and Pastures in Australian Farming Systems.
These issues were also discussed by the SCARM GAP Working Party 10 June, 24 July, 4 September and 13 November 1997.
The discussions were not connected to discussions of the new regulations for gene technology.
(10) Virus-resistant transgenic plants were discussed: By SCARM GAP Working Party on 10 June, 24 July, 4 September and 13 November 1997.

PIC 28 (October 1997) discussed the need for further work to be carried out to clarify the potential for a new virus to emerge as the result of viral recombination between plants carrying virus resistance genes and viruses that naturally infect plants.
(11) Members/secretariat officers of GMAC were:
(a) present at discussions referred to above.
(b) given the agenda or minutes.
Professor Nancy Millis, as Chair of the SCARM GAP Working Group was present at every meeting and would have been given both the minutes and the agenda for each meeting.

Andina Faragher, Gillian Allen and Kirsty McLean are GMAC staff who have provided Secretariat support for the SCARM GAP Working Group and one of them was present and provided with the agenda and minutes of each meeting.
(12) Officers or staff of the CSIRO were:
(a) present at discussions referred to above.
(b) given the agenda or minutes.
Dr Gary Fitt and Dr T J Higgins represented CSIRO on the SCARM GAP Working Group and one of them was present and provided with the agenda and minutes of each meeting.
(13) Yes, CSIRO is engaged in projects whose goal is to produce insect-resistant transgenic plants, herbicide-resistant transgenic plants and virus-resistant transgenic plants.
(14) The risks posed by virus-resistant transgenic plants were discussed at several meetings of the SCARM GAP and GMAC members would have taken part in the discussions.
(a) Professor Nancy Millis.
(b) on 10 June, 24 July, 4 September and 13 November 1997.
(c) Views presented are not attributable to individual members of the Working Group.
(d) Refer to the members listed in answers given to questions (1) and (2).
(15) The issue of the risks posed by virus-resistant transgenic plants was discussed at several meetings of the SCARM GAP Working Group. CSIRO officers took part in the discussions.
(a) Dr Gary Fitt and Dr T J Higgins.
(b) on 10 June, 24 July, 4 September and 13 November 1997.
(c) Views presented are not attributable to individual members of the Working Group.
(d) Refer to the members listed in answers given to questions (1) and (2).

(16) The SCARM Working Group to Prepare `Good Agricultural Practice Guidelines for Genetically Modified Crops and Pastures' decided to seek the views of a member of staff from the Cooperative Research Centre for Plant Science on the possible risks of using virus-resistant transgenic plants.

At the SCARM GAP Working Group meeting of 24 July 1997, Dr T J Higgins agreed to report on transcapsidation, sap-sucking insects and seed movement and other matters involving virus-resistant transgenic plants before next meeting. There was some discussion about the possibility of asking Dr Mark Gibbs to provide input on the risks relating to recombination and transcapsidation for farming systems, including the generation of new virus types with increased host range or virulence. No records indicate further discussions with Dr Gibbs.

This issue was discussed at PIC 28, in October 1997. A recommendation was made by the Workshop on the Commercialisation of Transgenic Crops and Pastures that the CRC for Plant Science prepare a concise `out-of-session issue paper for PIC on the issue of Risk Assessment of Viral Recombination in Transgenic Crops. Informal discussions were held with Dr Mark Gibbs from the CRC for Plant Science, about the possibility of Dr Gibbs producing a background paper on this topic. Dr Gibbs, at the time of writing, has not yet provided PIC with a formal proposal to write this paper and no views have yet been received by either committee from this CRC.

Sources: This information has been developed from the 1997 Minutes of the Plant Industries Committee and the SCARM Working Group to Prepare `Good Agricultural Practice Guidelines for Genetically Modified Crops and Pastures'.

talk.start.para: asked the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 13 May 1998:

question.para: (1) Will he provide a copy of the report of the drugs task force involved with the development of the `Tough on drugs' package and chaired by the Secretary of his Department; if not, why not.
(2) What (a) persons, (b) agencies and (c) governments were consulted by the task force in preparing the report and what form of consultation was involved in each case.
(3) How were the persons, agencies and governments referred to in part (2) chosen.
(4) If no consultation occurred, on what information and expertise was the report prepared.
(5) How many times did the task force meet in preparing the report and who attended each meeting.

(6) Were (a) State and Territory premiers, chief ministers or health ministers or (b) the Ministerial Council on Drug Strategy consulted specifically about the `Tough on drugs' package; if not, why not; if so, (i) when and (ii) by whom.

(7) What (a) outcomes measures have been established for the three components of the `Tough on drugs' package, (b) performance indicators have been developed to assess whether the outcomes have been achieved and (c) mechanisms have been implemented to monitor the achievement of the outcomes using the performance indicators.

(8) Have funds been allocated to treatment agencies under the `Tough on drugs' package; if so, (a) in each case (i) what sum, (ii) to whom and (iii) for what purpose, (b) which agencies applied for funding unsuccessfully and on what basis was funding refused in each case, (c) what process was used to distribute funds, (d) what criteria applied to the allocation of funds, (e) how were applications for funding assessed, (f) who assessed the applications, (g) were persons or bodies other than from the Department of Health and Family Services involved in the selection process; if so, (i) who and (ii) what were their qualifications, (h) will he provide a copy of the documentation provided to persons or agencies seeking funding for treatment services, (i) was the application process publicly announced; if so, (i) when and (ii) through which media; if not, why not, and (j) why were the funds not provided to the States and Territories through National Public Health Agreements.

(9) Was funding provided to the Alcohol and Other Drugs Council of Australia to assist in the implementation of the `Tough on drugs' package; if so, (a) what sum, (b) on what basis was it provided and (c) what activities was the Council to undertake.
(10) What progress has been made with the Schools Drug Strategy.
(11) Have funds been allocated under the Schools Drug Strategy; if so, (a) to whom, (b) for what activities and (c) what sum was provided in each case.

(12) Has $4.8 million been provided for local drug prevention and education projects; if so, (a) who has received funding, (b) how were they chosen, (c) what sum was provided in each case, (d) were outcomes or performance indicators developed; if not, why not; if so, what are they, and (e) what progress has been made in each case.
(13) Has $1.8 million been provided for a one-stop shop to disseminate information to the community; if so, what progress has been made.

(14) Has an agency been chosen to operate the service referred to in part (13); if so, (a) who, (b) how were they chosen, (c) on what basis was funding provided, (d) what outcomes are to be achieved, (e) was the funding publicly announced; if not, why not, and (f) did other agencies apply to conduct the service; if so (i) who and (ii) why were they not chosen.

(15) Have front line professionals been trained under the `Tough on drugs' package; if so, (a) what training did they receive, (b) who conducted the training, (c) to what professions do they belong, (d) what sums were they paid, (e) how were they selected, and (f) where are they located.

(16) Has interdisciplinary research been undertaken or funded by the National Health and Medical Research Council about the prevention and treatment of drug abuse; if so, in each case, (a) what was the nature of the research, (b) to whom was funding provided, (c) on what basis was funding provided and (d) what product was delivered to the Council.
(17) What funds have been provided to each State and Territory for the conduct of non-heroin trials.
(18) What trials are being undertaken and when will the results be known.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) No. The report was prepared as a Cabinet Memorandum and is covered by the conventions of Cabinet confidentiality.

(2) The task force's activities did not involve a consultation process as its purpose was to enable relevant Commonwealth Government agencies to collate and assess the range of Commonwealth activities relating to illicit drugs. Its work was therefore based on expert advice from relevant Commonwealth agencies.
(3) See the answer to part (2).
(4) See the answers to parts (2) and (3).
(5) The task force met twice. Members of the task force who attended the first meeting were:
. Mr Moore-Wilton (Secretary, Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet) (Chairman);
. Mr Flood (Secretary, Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade);
. Mr Podger (Secretary, Department of Health and Family Services);
. Mr Skehill (Secretary, Attorney-General's Department);
. Mr Broome (Chairman, National Crime Authority);
. Mr Palmer (Commissioner, Australian Federal Police);
. Mr Woodward (Chief Executive Officer, Australian Customs Service);
. Vice-Admiral Barrie (Vice-Chief of the Defence Force); and
. Mr Early (Deputy Secretary, Department of Finance).
The second meeting had the same attendance with the exception that Mr Reaburn (Acting Secretary, Attorney-General's Department) replaced Mr Skehill.

(6) The tough on drugs package was developed and announced in two instalments; the first was announced on 2 November 1997 and the second on 16 March 1998. State and Territory Governments were not consulted during the development of the first phase because its focus was primarily on identifying areas for Commonwealth leadership in response to the health, social and economic costs of illicit drug use in Australia including matters primarily within the Commonwealth's jurisdiction. After its announcement, the National Illicit Drug Strategy was discussed with Premiers and Chief Ministers at the Council of Australian Governments meeting on 7 November 1997. At that meeting Heads of Government agreed to join a National Illicit Drug Strategy, founded on a partnership between governments and the broader community. On 28 November 1997, the Minister for Health and Family Services, the Hon Dr Michael Wooldridge MP, wrote to Ministerial Council on Drug Strategy (MCDS) ministers asking for advice on suitable appointees to the Australian National Council on Drugs and its draft terms of reference. On 23 December 1997, Dr Wooldridge wrote to MCDS ministers about the implementation of the first instalment and their input to the development of additional measures which could be considered for inclusion in the second instalment.

(7) As part of the tough on drugs strategy, the terms of reference for the Australian National Council on Drugs require it to advise the Ministerial Council on Drug Strategy on the implementation and evaluation of the National Illicit Drug Strategy. More broadly, a National Drug Strategic Framework 1998-2002 is being developed and is currently the subject of widespread community consultation. Once the National Drug Strategic Framework has been endorsed by the Ministerial Council on Drug Strategy, performance indicators and mechanisms for monitoring these indicators will be developed for the whole of the National Drug Strategy, including the National Illicit Drug Strategy. In anticipation of this, evaluation and, where appropriate, data collection is being built into the individual components of the National Illicit Drug Strategy.
(b)â(g) See the answer to (a).

(h) I understand a copy of the documentation provided to persons or agencies seeking funding for treatment services has been provided to the honour able member by the Department of Health and Family Services.
(i) Yes; advertisements appeared in major metropolitan newspapers and the indigenous press in the week beginning 30 May 1998.

(j) The National Illicit Drug Strategy shows Commonwealth leadership to address illicit drug problems. This leadership is consistent with the approach called for by the 1997 evaluation of the National Drug Strategy.

(10) The development, implementation and progress of the Schools Drug Education Strategy will be informed by the National Advisory Committee on Schools Drug Education which was established on 22 April 1998 by the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training, Senator the Hon Christopher Ellison. The Schools Drug Education Strategy is currently in draft form and is being considered by the National Advisory Committee.

The National Advisory Committee will provide expert advice and direction on the Schools Drug Education Strategy to the Minister and through the Minister to the Ministerial Council on Education, Employment, Training and Youth Affairs.

The National Advisory Committee on Schools Drug Education will also report to the Ministerial Council on Drug Strategy through the Inter-Governmental Committee on Drugs and the Australian National Council on Drugs.

(11) No funds have been allocated under the Schools Drug Education Strategy. The funding of $7.5 million over three years begins in financial year 1998-99. However, to inform the development of the Strategy, the Curriculum Corporation conducted a project on behalf of the Commonwealth to provide a comprehensive data base of drug education materials currently being used in Australian primary and secondary schools and drug education policy materials. The project was funded from the Quality Outcomes Program of the Department of Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs at a cost of $23,375.

(12) While the Government has made provision for the community grants program, funds have not been allocated. Advertisements appeared in major metropolitan newspapers and the indigenous press in the week beginning 30 May 1998 seeking applications from agencies for funding local drug prevention and education projects.

(13) While the Government has made provision for a national one stop shop, no funds have been allocated to an organisation to provide a one stop shop. Implementation of this initiative is currently being considered by the Australian National Council on Drugs.
(14) See the answer to part (13).
(15) While the Government has made provision for the training of front line professionals, no funds have been allocated for training under this provision.
(16) The Government has funded three research projects under the National Illicit Drug Strategy.
(a) The prediction of emotional and behavioural problemsâinfancy to adolescence;
(b) University of Melbourne.
(a) Investigation of cocaine induced changes in brain function;
(b) Flinders University.
(a) Parenting in the socio-cultural context of illicit drug or harmful alcohol use (A Research Training Fellowship);
(b) Australian National University.
(c) All three grants were provided on the basis of competitive applications under the 1997 NHMRC grant round funding for 1998. The total funding for these grants over four years is $735,000.
(d) The research fellowship grant is for four years and the other two grants are for three year projects. Accordingly, results will not be available for some time.

(17) A total of $58,170 under the National Drug Strategy was provided in 1996-97 towards a multi-site two year clinical trial of buprenorphine, which is being conducted in New South Wales and South Australia. Funds have not been allocated to States and Territories for the conduct of non-heroin trials under the National Illicit Drugs Strategy.

(18) To the knowledge of the Department of Health and Family Services, the State trials which are currently under way include the pilot stage of a trial of naltrexone withdrawal in New South Wales, and a trial of buprenorphine maintenance in South Australia and New South Wales. Extensive data from the buprenorphine trial are expected in December 1998 with final results and analysis upon trial completion in March 2000.
Several other jurisdictions have announced their intentions to undertake trials. As the Commonwealth is not involved in undertaking the trials, it is not known when results will be available.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Workplace Relations and Small Business, upon notice, on 14 May 1998:

question.para: (1) Has the Australian Industrial Relations Commission (AIRC) heard the submissions concerning the lockout of miners at the Gordonstone Mine in Central Queensland which is owned by Atlantic Richfield Oil Company (ARCO).
(2) Did the Gordonstone management admit before the AIRC that the unionised workforce were good employees.

(3) Did the AIRC (a) find that the terminations of employment had to do with the capacity and conduct of senior management, not that of employees, and, more specifically, an intent on the part of senior management to avoid its statutory obligations and (b) conclude that the dismissals were harsh, unjust and unreasonable.
(4) Will he urge ARCO to (a) behave decently towards its employees wherever it operates in Australia; and (b) respect the traditions of unionism which exist in Australia.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) There was no lockout of miners at the Gordonstone coal mine. Gordonstone Coal Management Pty Ltd, a subsidiary of ARCO Coal Australia Inc, retrenched all of its 312 production and engineering employees on 1 October 1997 and placed the mine on an indefinite care and maintenance program.

As a consequence of the retrenchments, the CFMEU made applications on behalf of 282 of the former employees under s170CE(1) of the Workplace Relations Act 1996 (the act), claiming unfair termination of employment. In order to expedite proceedings, the Australian Industrial Relations Commission (AIRC) decided to arbitrate seven representative cases.

(2) In his decision of 2 February 1998 on the representative cases, Hingley C stated that he was satisfied that, from the submissions of the company, the "workforce were at all times generally good employees whose individual personal work records were not taken into account in the decision to terminate the entire [production & engineering] workforce".

At the time of the retrenchments, mine management said that it had continually tried to implement change to meet the mine owner's requirement for improved performance in safety, productivity and costs. Gordonstone indicated that it had been unable to achieve the necessary rate of improvement given the structures, systems, behaviours and work organisation that existed at the mine.

(3) (a) and (b) Hingley C found that "each of the seven representative terminations were harsh, unjust and unreasonable". In his reasons for the decision, the Commissioner makes the statement: "I am of the view that the terminations of employment had to do with the capacity and conduct of senior management not that of the employees, and more specifically, an intent on the part of senior management to avoid its statutory obligations".

(4) (a) and (b) The Government expects all employers, employees, and unions to fully comply with the relevant laws, including the Workplace Relations Act 1996. In an industry such as coal mining, regardless of its traditions, it urges employers and employees to work cooperatively to improve competitiveness and efficiency in their own interests and in the national interest.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Defence Industry, Science and Personnel, upon notice, on 25 May 1998:

question.para: What fire protection clothing is provided to sailors in the RAN and in what circumstances is it required to be worn.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: When onboard a ship officers and sailors in the Royal Australian Navy (RAN) are provided with the following protective clothing, which is worn over normal cotton underwear; combat coveralls (proban treated), anti flash hood and gloves (proban treated), safety boots, and fearnought suits.
The RAN has three levels of clothing and equipment for dealing with fires. These are as follows:

Basic firefighting dressâ This consists of combat coveralls, anti flash hood, gloves and safety boots. This dress is worn to conduct initial firefighting using portable (hand held) extinguishers. Duty personnel who are required to respond to a fire alarm will wear the coveralls and safety boots and carry the hood and gloves.

Intermediate firefighting dressâThis consists of the basic firefighting dress with the addition of breathing apparatus. Personnel in this dress will be used to carry out second level firefighting using portable extinguishers in the presence of smoke or toxic fumes.

Full firefighting dressâThis consists of the basic firefighting dress with the addition of a fearnought suit (constructed of woollen fire retardant material) and breathing apparatus. This dress is used by personnel with fire hoses to conduct major firefighting.
In addition, firefighters at the Naval Air Station, Nowra wear protective clothing to the same standard as firefighters at civil airports.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts, upon notice, on 27 May 1998:

question.para: (1) Is it a fact that Vodafone is maintaining its analogue service in the UK.
(2) Could Vodafone compete with an analogue service in Australia; if not, why not.
(3) Is it a fact that neither Vodafone nor Optus have bought an allocation of the spectrum in regional Australia; if so, what are the implications for rural Australia.

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

answer.para: (1) Vodafone (Australia) advises that Vodafone (UK and Cellnet) opened its analogue services in the UK in 1985. Vodafone subsequently introduced GSM and has been gradually closing down the UK analogue network over the last few years to re-deploy the radio channels to GSM use.

Vodafone advises that it has invested significant sums in the UK in the management of this migration both in capital investment and in enabling the customers to upgrade their equipment from analogue service to GSM.

Vodafone reports that its analogue customer base has declined as a result of this gradual migration and closure program from a peak of some 2 million in 1995 to approximately 750 thousand today, and that Cellnet's profile is similar.
Vodafone advises that the analogue networks in the UK will be completely closed by 2005.

(2) Within the terms of its Public Telecommunications Mobile Licence Service (PMTS) under both the Telecommunications Act 1991 (the 1991 Act) and the Telecommunications Act 1997 (the 1997 Act), Vodafone advises that it could resell the analogue service provided by Telstra through to 31 December 1999, when the service is to be phased out (subject to limited exemptions).

Vodafone has said that, on the basis of this undertaking by the Government, Vodafone has invested over $1 billion in digital GSM infrastructure in Australia, since its licence was awarded in December 1992. It has been unable to justify any additional expenditure to provide connection and billing services so it can resell the Telstra analogue service in competition with it's own GSM digital network.

(3) Vodafone advises that at the auction of spectrum in the 800 and 1800 Mhz bands in late May 1998, it purchased additional spectrum in the 1800 Mhz band in Brisbane, Sydney, Melbourne, Adelaide, Perth Canberra, Tasmania and Darwin.

Vodafone advises that it previously acquired 5 Mhz of spectrum in the 900 Mhz band Australia wide through its PMTS licence in 1992, and subsequently, with Telstra and Optus, was allocated another 3.3 Mhz making a total of 8.3 Mhz of paired spectrum in the 900 Mhz band.
Vodafone advises that the spectrum acquired is more than enough capacity to satisfy all Vodafone mobile telephony capacity requirements in rural Australia for the foreseeable future.
Optus advises that it purchased spectrum in the 1.8 Ghz band in Sydney, Melbourne, Brisbane, Adelaide and Perth primarily to address anticipated future congestion in these cities.

Optus advises that it did not purchase additional spectrum in rural areas because its current spectrum allocation (900 Mhz) in these areas is more than sufficient to cater for the expected demand. Optus believes that its decision regarding the auction has no implications for rural Australia.
Optus advises that over 91% of the Australian population currently has access to Optus' mobile

digital services. Optus' plans to increase its coverage are very aggressive with 500 base stations planned for 1997/98 and 650 planned for 1998/99. Rural Australia will also receive a significant increase in mobile coverage with more than 100 new rural sites planned for 1998/99.
